text: An establishing shot of the rundown train station on an  overcast morning. There's snow on the station platform. A train arrives and departs.
In other parts of the world, young  men of promise leave home to make  their fortunes, battle evil, or solve  the problems of the world.
Behind the station, at the top of the hill, lies the St.  Cloud's orphanage.
I was myself such a young man, when  I came to save the orphanage in St.  Cloud's... many years ago.
A man and woman (COUPLE #1) make their way toward the mai entrance of the large brick building.

Here in St. Cloud's, I have come to  understand that promises are rarely  kept, that the battle isn't so much  against evil as ignorance, and that  being successful can't hold a candle  to being of *use*.
The couple enters the orphanage, where we hear the sound babies.
Nor have I solved the problem I came  here to solve.
Two nurses, EDNA and ANGELA, chase CHILDREN--a morning  routine.

Even in the most enlightened times,  unwanted babies will manage to be  born. That there will always be  orphans is simple not a problem to  be solved. Here is St. Cloud's, we  don't regard the sordid facts of  life as problems.
The camera goes up the stairs with some of the kids.
We enter an office where DR. LARCH shows couple #1 their  newly adopted son, HOMER, an infant who lies smiling in D Larch's arms.
In truth, we've only had one real  problem.
We close in on the infant until his face fills the screen
His name was Homer Wells.
Dr. Larch hands over the infant to the adopting parents.
I named him after the Greek writer.  You know Homer, of course?
Hesitant nods. (They don't look as if they read.)
I made his name "Wells" because I  could tell he was very deep.
The parents look with pride at their adopted son.
In truth, Nurse Angela named him-- her father *drilled* wells, and  "Homer" was one of her family's  umpteen cats.
At the front door, Larch and the nurses wave and call goo bye to Homer, they close the door.
The same door swings open; it's another night. The same c is bringing Homer back. There is concern in their faces a Nurse Edna lets them in.
Larch is delivering his benediction to the boys.
"Good night, you Princes of Maine,  you Kings of New England!"
As he turns, he is startled by Nurse Edna, waiting with c #1 and baby Homer.
There's something wrong with him! He  never makes a sound.
Larch looks quickly at Homer.
He didn't cry enough for them, if  you can believe it.
Do you think we could have a look at  someone a little different?
The mother hands over the baby to Larch. Baby Homer lets a happy squeal as soon as he's in Larch's arms. The paren stare in disbelief.
Thus was Homer Wells returned. He  was too happy a baby.
Angela and Edna call and wave good-bye to a two-year-old  Homer, leaving with COUPLE #2. Larch stands on the porch watches the family head down the hill.
The second family has an unfortunate  gift for getting sounds out of Homer.
Larch bursts into the home of the second couple and lifts crying and bruised Homer out of his bed. There is rage in Larch's eyes as he looks at the couple.
The rumor was true. They beat him.  He couldn't stop crying.
Larch carries Homer up the orphanage hill.
Here is St. Cloud's, I try to  consider, with each rule I make or  break, that my first priority is an  orphan's future.
The naked belly of a VERY PREGNANT WOMAN.
Easier said than done.

A tiny hand comes in with a stethoscope and puts it on th big belly. Young Homer's head, with the stethoscope aroun his neck, pops up behind the belly; he closes his eyes as concentrates on listening to the sounds of the unborn chi Larch stops in the doorway, catching sight of Homer. He s faintly.
The door opens to a THIRD COUPLE smiling at us, welcoming and embracing a sixteen-year-old Homer. Behind them waits the would-be STEPSISTER--an attractive girl, a little old then Homer.
I told the third family to take good  care--this was a special boy.
Homer and the stepsister are in bed together. The parents burst in on them--the father chasing Homer around and aro the bed, the mother beating her daughter, who covers hers with a pillow.
It was Homer who took too much good  care of himself.
From her window, the stepsister watches Homer leave the h carrying his suitcase. Homer looks up at her as he walks the street.

It's after dawn, but still a little dark, as Homer walks the orphanage door, suitcase in hand. A HUGELY PREGNANT W arrives at the same time. They stand awkwardly next to ea other, waiting for someone to answer the door. The woman crying. Homer reaches out and takes her hand.
Don't be frightened. Everyone is  nice here.
Do you live here?
I just belong here.
The woman sniffles; she nods vaguely. The door opens. Nur Edna lets the woman in and embraces Homer.
What could I do with him? He kept  coming back!
Larch instructs an older Homer from "Gray's Anatomy." Hom is bored and looks out the window.
Homer, if you're going to stay at  St. Cloud's, I expect you to be of  use.
Homer looks adoringly at Dr. Larch as Larch examines ANOT PREGNANT WOMAN. Larch waves Homer over; he places the boy hand on the woman's abdomen, to feel the fetus kicking.
But, in failing to withhold love,  had I created a true and everlasting  orphan? I had been too successful  with Homer Wells. I had managed to  make the orphanage his *home*.
Larch closes a door quickly behind him (so that Homer doe see the ABORTION PATIENT in the O.R.)
Homer assists Larch in delivering a BABY.
Homer carries a white enamel pail to the incinerator. He  looks inside the pail; he stops.
God forgive me. I have *made* an  orphan by loving him too much. Homer  Wells will belong to St. Cloud's,  forever.
Hold on Homer's disgusted expression as he stares at the  contents of the pail. END TITLE SEQUENCE. FADE OUT. We hear a song playing on a old phonograph.

We see the song playing on the old phonograph. Dr. Larch taking ether. He holds the bottle in one hand, the cone o his mouth and nose with the other. SUPER: ST. CLOUD'S, MAINE, MARCH 1943. When Larch dozes off, his hand loosens its grip on the co the cone falls off his face, and he wakes up. Then he put the cone back in place, dripping more ether from the bott to the gauze covering the cone. Pan the dispensary, which also serves as Larch's photo ga and bedroom apartment. The ether-bed is separated from th room by a hospital curtain (the kind on casters). We see recording revolving, the glass-encased cabinets of medica supplies, the old photographs of St. Cloud's. Homer enters, he stands uncomfortably, watching Larch for moment. Then he turns around and walks back into the corr
Homer calls out as though he's just coming down the corri
Dr. Larch! Dr. Larch!
Larch wakes up; he shakes off the ether haze. Homer reent
We've got two new patients, one to  deliver.
Dr. Larch and Homer leave together.
The *two* doctors walk briskly down the hall, a couple of professionals.
First pregnancy?
Yes, for both.
(sarcastically) I presume you'd prefer handling the  delivery.
(tiredly; an old topic) All I said was, I don't want to  perform abortions. I have no argument  with *you* performing them.
You know *how* to help these women-- how can you not feel *obligated* to  help them when they can't get help  anywhere else?
One: it's illegal. Two: I didn't ask  how to do it--you just showed me.
What *else* could I have showed you,  Homer? The only thing I can teach  you is what I know! In every life,  you've got to be of use.
Homer and Larch split off and disappear into two differen operating rooms. As he goes, Homer mumbles to himself, "O use, of use, of use."
Larch and Angela are preparing the ether for DOROTHY, a n visibly pregnant woman. The sounds of labor across the ha can be heard Over.
(holds the cone) Have you ever had ether, Dorothy?
Once, when they took out my appendix.
(looks for scar) No one's touched your appendix.
Whatever it was... the ether made me  sick.
It won't make you sick this time,  Dorothy--not the way I do it, just a  drop at a time.
I can't pay for this, you know--I  got no money.
One day, Dorothy, if you have any  money, a donation to the orphanage  would be very much appreciated.
Only if you can afford it.
(holds the ether bottle) Try to think of nothing, Dorothy.
Angela puts the cone over Dorothy's mouth and nose; Larch drips the ether on the cone. A newborn wails in the other O.R. Over.
Homer has delivered CARLA. A newborn baby is screaming in Edna's arms. Homer is attending to Carla, who is panting.
That was good, Carla--that was  *perfect*. Everything's fine.
I don't wanna see it!
You don't have to see it, dear. Don't  worry.
I don't even wanna know what sex it  is--don't tell me!
We won't tell you, Carla. You're  going to be okay.
Your *baby's* going to be okay, too.
I don't wanna know!
Larch pops into the delivery room; he peers at the baby.
He's a big boy!
Let me see him, for Christ's sake--I  wanna see him.
Edna shows the baby to Carla, who stares, then turns away Larch whispers to Homer.
Would you mind having a look at  Dorothy?
Angela sits with the still-etherized Dorothy while Larch Homer confer over a basin containing Dorothy's uterus.
There was no visible wound?
No. The fetus was dead. Her uterus  was virtually *disintegrating*--my  stitches pulled right through the  tissue!
(mystified) It looks like scurvy.
(derisively sarcastic) Scurvy! Ah yes, the curse of the old- time sailor, suffering long periods  at sea with no fresh fruits or  vegetables. Homer, Dorothy isn't a  *sailor*!
She's a prostitute, isn't she?
(to Angela) Did you look in her purse?
(frustrated) I looked everywhere else!
Angela hands Larch a bottle of brown liquid.
It's called French Lunar Solution.
Larch wrinkles his nose at the odor.
It's not ergot, it's not pituitary  extract, it's not oil of rue...
It claims to restore monthly  regularity.
It's obviously an aborticide.
Obviously.
Larch wets his finger with the stuff, then touches it to tongue.
(spits) Christ, it's oil of tansy!
I don't know it.
If you take enough of it, your  intestines lose their ability to  absorb Vitamin C.
In other words, scurvy.
Good boy. Good job. And you call  yourself "not a doctor"! (to Angela) Keep an eye on her--she's in trouble.
As Homer turns to leave, Larch stops him; he points to th basin.
Take care of that, will you?
Homer stops, annoyed; he picks up the basin and empties t contents into a white enamel pail.

MISS TITCOMB is teaching math to some distracted boys and girls in a corner of the dining room. A blackboard on whe is a mass of numbers. Homer, passing through the dining r with the white enamel pail, attracts the attention of BUS a sixteen-year-old who is picking over a plate of pastrie on a table. Buster immediately goes with Homer.
I'll help you.
Homer shakes his head, keeps walking. Buster follows. Dr. Larch passes close to Buster. Buster makes a face, disgus
Buster and Homer tramp through the snow toward the  incinerator. Homer still carries the pail.
He *sniffs* that ether! I've seen  him do it!
It's because he's too tired to sleep.  He has to.
He *smells* like he could put you to  sleep!
He's a doctor, Buster--doctors smell  like ether.
*You're* a doctor, Homer--you don't  smell like ether.
I'm *not* a doctor. I haven't been  to medical school--I haven't even  been to high school!
But you've studied with the old man  for *years*!
I'm *not* a doctor!
I'm sorry, Homer.
Buster stands watching as Homer empties the pail into the incinerator.

With his head inclined to the giant ear of Larch's phonog FUZZY--six, thin, and pale and looking remarkably like an embryo--is listening to a recording. He can't hear what L and Homer are saying about him as they construct a humidi tent over a small hospital bed on wheels. The humidifier operated by a car battery.
Fuzzy is not uncommon. I tell you,  there's something about the premature  babies of alcoholic mothers. They  seem susceptible to every damn thing  that comes along.
I haven't read that.
I haven't, either. But you *will*.  The morons who write the books should  do a little research *here*.
But isn't Fuzzy just... well,  underdeveloped?
When *doesn't* he have bronchitis? I  wouldn't call his bronchial infections  "underdeveloped." Would you?
Larch plucks Fuzzy from in front of the phonograph and zi him into the breathing tent. Fuzzy smiles. As larch leave MARY AGNES, a pretty but tough-looking teenager, comes in the dispensary.
What is it, Mary Agnes?

Mary Agnes smiles at Homer; then she sticks her tongue ou at him. Homer looks at her impassively, but as the moment continues his expression suggests his annoyance. Fuzzy st to cough; he wheezes as he breathes. Homer leans down; he peers at Fuzzy through a hole by the zipper of the tent.
(garbled because of  her tongue) Look!
Homer examines Mary Agnes' tongue.
Did you bite it?
I don't remember.
(dismissively) It looks like you bit it--it'll be  all right.
Maybe I was kissing someone and he  bit me.
(looks at her tongue  again) No, you did it yourself. Maybe in  your sleep.
I must have been *dreaming* of kissing  someone.
Homer is not responding to her come-on. He wheels Fuzzy i the hall.
Story time, Fuzzy!
In the girls' bunk room, Nurse Edna is saying prayers. Th girls lie with their palms pressed together on their ches
"Oh Lord, support us all the day  long..."
The building of St. Cloud's is silhouetted against the sk Carla, the woman we saw deliver the baby, is heading down the hill alone, she sobs, not looking back.
"...until the shadows lengthen and  the evening comes, and the busy world  is hushed, and the fever of life is  over, and our work is done."
In the bunk room again, with Edna and the girls.
"Then in Thy mercy grant us save  lodging, and holy rest, and peace at  the last."
Amen! Amen! Amen!
Dr. Larch is reading from Oliver Twist--the death scene o Bill Sike's dog. The boys listen in horror in their beds.
"A dog, which had lain concealed  till now, ran backwards and forwards  on the parapet with a dismal howl,  and collecting himself for a spring,  jumped for the dead man's shoulders."
Homer enters; he walks quietly to his bed in the far corn of the room, where he starts to undress.
"Missing his aim, he fell into a  ditch, turning completely over as he  went; and striking his head against  a stone, dashed his brains out.
Larch turns out the lights. From the open doorway to the  hall, Larch delivers his nightly benediction.
Good night, you Princes of Maine!  You Kings of New England!
Larch closes the door, leaving them in the semi-darkness. One young boy runs into Homer's bed, nervously giggling.
(in his breathing  tent) Why does Dr. Larch *do* tht every  night?
(about seven) Maybe to scare us...
(about eleven) No, you jerk.
(about nine) Dr. Larch *loves* us!
But why does he do *that*?
He does it because we like it.
The boys silently agree, Homer among them.
The girls, led by Mary Agnes, round a corner of the orpha towing a sled piled high with snowballs.
Buster is mine. You two get  Copperfield and Curly. Nobody touches  Fuzzy.

They shriek as the boys suddenly surprise them. Buster th two hard snowballs that hit Mary Agnes and CLARA (eight o nine) before Mary Agnes overwhelms him and repeatedly sti his head in the snow. Copperfield, terrified of Mary Agne escapes. Curly misses, then tips over the sled of snowbal as Clara and the adorable HAZEL (five or six) throw him t the ground. Fuzzy drops his one snowball; he runs aimless in circles, coughing, as Nurse Edna explodes from a door the orphanage.
Stop it! No fighting! *Share* the  snowballs!
(mouth full of snow) They're *our* snowballs! They *stole*  them!
They attacked us--just like the Japs!
Fuzzy coughs and wheezes, trying to catch his breath.
Listen to you, Fuzzy! You've been  running. You get to the shower!

A NEW COUPLE comes up the hill. The orphans stop and star brushing snow off themselves, struggling to make themselv look presentable. Curly is desperate to look his best. Ma Agnes doesn't bother to pretty herself. She whispers to C and Hazel.
I know the type--they'll take one of  the babies.

The children are eating breakfast as the would-be parents walk around the tables, looking over the assembled orphan Curly works on his table manners; he forks and eats a pie of pancake with elegance. Angela and Edna try to make the couple slow down by the older children, but the couple st and stare at the adorable Hazel.
Larch and Homer are examining the babies. The doctors are checking the babies' grips, their eyes, ears, and throats Angela appears in the doorway.
Wilbur, the adopting couple is waiting  in your office.
(irritated) Life is waiting.
Angela disappears. Larch looks at the next baby's record  (attached to the bed).
Where's the name sheet?
Nobody's named this one yet.
It's my turn!
Homer is tired of this game. Larch touches the child's  forehead with his index finger.
Henceforth you shall be... Little  Dorrit!
The baby starts to cry.
He doesn't like it. (looks at the record) He's a boy, That's why.
Can't a boy be a Dorrit?
I don't think so.
You do it then.
Homer points his finger at the child's forehead like a gu
Henceforth you shall be... Little  Wilbur.
I'm not crazy about the "Little..."
Homer is writing the name.
Okay, he's just a Wilbur then.
We haven't had a Wilbur here in a  year or so, have we? We used to have  *dozens*!
They are interrupted by Copperfield, who comes running fr the corridor.
They picked Hazel! The idiots chose  Hazel!
Hazel is being fussed over by Edna. Hazel clutches a card suitcase and a tattered rag doll. Mary Agnes, by far the  oldest, sits on a bed.
If people want to adopt one of us,  they should have to take the oldest  first.
Please, Mary Agnes! This is Hazel's  special day--don't make her feel  sad.
Hazel's practically the youngest of  us. She should be the *last* to leave!
At least Hazel can talk. Usually  they take one of the stupid babies.
They take the babies so they won't  ever have to tell them that they  were orphans!
(begins to cry) I'm not a baby!
If you cry, Hazel, they'll just send  you back.
Mary Agnes, that's not true!
Hazel cries harder.
That's what they did to me!
You *wanted* to come back--that's  why you cried. (to Hazel) You can cry if you feel like it,  Hazel. You cry as much as you want.
Homer is in the corridor outside the office, overhearing  Larch's lecture to the couple adopting Hazel.

It is strictly for our orphans' sake  that I destroy any record of their  natural mothers. Of course they will,  one day, want to know. But orphans,  especially, should look forward to  their *futures*. Not back to their  pasts.
Homer sees Curly standing all alone by a window in the  corridor; a suitcase is next to him.
Hi, Curly. You going somewhere?
Curly shakes his head.
I thought they might take me.
They wanted a girl.
Nobody ever wants me!
Homer embraces Curly and lifts him up, he grabs the suitc and continues down the corridor.
You're one of the best, Curly--we  couldn't let just anyone take you.
Dr. Larch wouldn't let just anyone  take *any* of us!
That's true.
Nobody's asked for me, have they?
Nobody special enough, Curly.
You mean somebody asked?
Only the right people can have you,  Curly.
Homer disappears into the boys' bunk room carrying Curly his suitcase, leaving the corridor empty.
Faces in the windows; the orphans watch Hazel walking acr the snowy lawn with her new parents.
Edna (with the girls) gives her good-bye blessing to Haze
Let us be happy for Hazel. Hazel has  found a family. Good night, Hazel.
Good night, Hazel! Good night, Hazel!  Good night, Hazel!
The front door opens. The orphans excitedly run outside o the green lawn, into the warm weather of spring.

Angela is singing along with the song on the phonograph, more romantic song then before, which rouses Larch from h ether. He is grumpy, but she sings the song in his ear an won't give him back the ether cone; he rolls away from he but she tickles him and bites his ear, coaxing him into a more playful mood.
I was dreaming about you. How  beautiful you were!
You weren't dreaming about me.
I was!
Playfully, she slips out of his embrace.
Then I wasn't beautiful.
You were! You *are*! It was fantastic.
It was just the ether, Wilbur...
Homer wheels a tray with glasses of water between the bed A DISTRAUGHT PREGNANT WOMAN stops him by her bed.
Are you okay? Can I get you anything?
No one but me ever put a hand on me,  to feel that baby. Don't you want to  touch it or put your ear down to it?
Okay.
Homer touches the woman's belly.
Put your ear there. Go on.
Homer cautiously lays his ear against her belly.
You shouldn't have a baby if there's  no one who wants to put his face  right there!
She holds Homer's head against her belly; she presses his face into her. She shuts her eyes. Homer's eyes stare wid Dr. Larch stops in the doorway; he watches with concern.
Stay right there. Right where you  are. Stay right here. Right here.
Homer at the train station, staring down the empty tracks Buster is hanging around with him, kicking a rock.
Do you ever think about leaving this  place to go find them?

Homer makes no response. As the train approaches, Homer a Buster go sit on a loading cart. They see the distraught  woman (no longer pregnant) from Homer's experience of a f nights ago; she is leaving St. Cloud's without her baby,  waiting for the approaching train. Her face is a mask. Th DISAPPROVING STATIONMASTER gives her a hard look.
I mean your parents.
I know who you mean. I think about  leaving here, but not to find *them*.
Why not?
Whoever they were, they didn't *do*  any of the things parents are supposed  to do. Dr. Larch did those things,  and Nurse Edna, and Nurse Angela.
Yeah. But sometimes I wish I could  meet mine, anyway.
What for, Buster? What would you do  if you met them?
Uh... I'd like to show them that I  can cook, a little.
You cook very well!
And that I can drive a truck!
(laughing) Better than I can!
Sometimes I want to meet them so I  can kill them. Just sometimes.
Buster is ashamed; he knows he's said the wrong thing.
Homer, you know I would never kill  anyone--you know I wouldn't.
I know.

The slowly moving train has stopped. There are SOLDIERS  leaning out the windows. Buster turns to see Mary Agnes  walking past the train--she's doing her best to look grow up, sophisticated. One of the soldiers reaches out and ge tugs on  her hair. Mary Agnes is enraged; she spits at th soldier.
I think Mary Agnes could kill someone.
I doubt it. She's just an...
Mary Agnes spits at *all* the soldiers.
...emotional girl.
The soldiers roll up the windows as Mary Agnes improvises some verbal abuse.
What's she so emotional about?
(shrugs) I don't know. She got left here,  like the rest of us, didn't she?
Camera closes on Homer.

The orphans are watching King Kong, the part when the gia ape first captures the screaming Fay Wray. Intercut Kong  with the orphans' rapt faces. Homer sits near the front,  mesmerized by the film. Dr. Larch and Angela sit by the  projector; Larch is reading a letter. Fuzzy points to the screen.
(coughing) He thinks she's his *mother*!
King Kong is undressing Fay Wray in the cave.
He doesn't think she's his mother,  Fuzzy.
He does so! He *loves* her!
How could she be his *mother*?
Larch shakes the letter in front of Angela.
(a harsh whisper) They want to replace me! The Board  of Trustees wants to *replace* me!
(whispering back) They just want you to hire some new  help.
Some new *things* would be useful. I  don't need any "new help."

The film breaks--to huge cries of disappointment from the orphans. Fuzzy coughs and coughs while Larch fumbles with the projector. Angela turns on the light while Larch squi at the broken film. The orphans are chanting, "Kong! Kong
Homer! I need you!
Homer gets up and walks to the projector.
I thought you took care of this. It  always breaks in the same place.  It's your splice, isn't it?
(angry) It's *your* splice! You blame me for  everything!
Larch abruptly lets go of the film.
Angela, we need a new movie, a new  projector, a new typewriter--*that's*  what they should replace around here!
Edna comes in; she speaks to Larch, then quickly leaves.
We have a delivery. Imminent, in my  estimation...
Larch turns to Homer.
Homer, would you get this one?
Homer shifts his weight to the other foot; aggravated; he stands there.
She's a patient, right? She should  see a doctor.
Homer and Larch stare at each other.
(trying to stay calm) Homer, you are a skilled and gifted  surgeon. You have near-prefect  obstetrical and gynecological  procedure.
Homer is also trying to avoid a fight.
I just mean I'd rather fix the movie.  Tonight.
Larch can't hide his disappointment.
Sure. Okay. You splice. I'll deliver.
It is an uneasy peace.
Homer is adjusting Fuzzy's breathing tent as the other bo climb into bed.
Homer... doesn't King Kong think the  woman is his *mother*?
Uh, sure--that's what Kong thinks,  all right.
That's why Kong loves her!
Larch comes in and walks over to Homer and Fuzzy. Larch a Homer exchange a look.
I thought it was my turn.
It is. I'll get this. You go ahead.
Homer sits down with 'David Copperfield.' There is quiet  anticipation while Homer readies himself to read.
(reading) "Whether I shall turn out to be the  hero of my own life, or whether that  station will be held by anybody else,  these pages must show."
Larch continues to adjust Fuzzy's breathing tent.
"I was a posthumous child. My father's  eyes had closed upon the light of  this world six months, when mine  opened on it."
(whispers to Larch) His father's dead, right?
(whispering back) That's right, Fuzz.
Close on Fuzzy.
(continues reading) "There is something strange to me,  even now, in the reflection that he  never saw me..."
As Larch bends over Fuzzy to fix the breathing apparatus, Fuzzy whispers.
Is *your* father dead?
(nods, whispers) Cirrhosis--it's a disease of the  liver.
*Liver* killed him?
*Alcohol* killed him--he drank himself  to death.
But did you know him?
Barely. It hardly mattered that I  knew him.
Did you know your mother better?
(nods, still whispers) She's dead now, too. She was a nanny.
What's a nanny do?
She looks after other people's  children.
Did you grow up around here?
No. She was an immigrant.
What's an immigrant?
Someone not from Maine.
The orphanage in moonlight. Not a sound.
The children are chasing a ball near the incinerator. A VERY FRIGHTENED GIRL---not one of the orphans--is lying next to the incinerator. Edna kneels by the strange girl, who cringes with fear.
No one's going to hurt you, dear.  Have you come to visit us? We have  beds, you know. Have you had any  breakfast? What's your name?
The girl won't speak; when Edna touches the girl's forehe she pulls back her hand in alarm.

Edna is holding the head of the frightened young girl. Th girl is feverishly hot and whimpering; she keeps looking her feet in the stirrups as if she's an animal caught in trap. Larch and Homer stand on either side of her.
Her temperature is a hundred and  four.
(very gently) How old are you, dear? Thirteen?
The girl shakes her head. The pain stabs her again.
Twelve? Are you twelve, dear? (the girl nods) You have to tell me how long you've  been pregnant. (the girl freezes) Three months?
Another stab of pain contorts the girl.
Are you *four* months pregnant?
The girl holds her breath while he examines her abdomen;  Homer very delicately examines the girl's abdomen, too.
(whispers to Larch) She's at least *five*.
The girl goes rigid as Larch bends into position.
Dear child, it won't hurt when I  look. I'm just going to *look*.
Homer assists Larch with the speculum.
Tell me: you haven't done something  to yourself, have you?
It wasn't me!
Did you go to someone else?
He said he was a doctor. I would  never have stuck that inside me!
Stuck *what* inside you?
Homer holds the girl still--she is babbling on and on whi Larch is examining her.
It wasn't me! I would never do no  such thing! I wouldn't stick that  inside me! It wasn't me!

Larch, his wild eye peering into the speculum, makes an  audible gasp from the shock of what he sees inside the gi Larch tells Homer to have a look. Larch then whispers  something to Edna; she brings the ether bottle and cone  quickly. Larch starts putting the cone in place, over the nose and mouth of the frightened girl. Homer bends to the speculum.
(to the twelve-year- old) Listen, you've been very brave. I'm  going to put you to sleep--you won't  feel it anymore. You've been brave  enough.
Homer stares into the speculum; he closes his eyes. The g is resisting the ether, but her eyelids flutter closed.
That's a heavy sedation.
You *bet* it's a heavy sedation! The  fetus is unexpelled, her uterus is  punctured, she has acute peritonitis,  and there's a foreign object. I think  it's a crochet hook.
Homer has pulled off his surgical mask. He leans over the scrub sink, splashing cold water on his face.

(to Homer) If she'd come to you four months ago  and asked you for a simple D and C,  what would you have decided to do?  *Nothing*? *This* is what doing  nothing gets you, Homer. It means  that someone else is going to do the  job--some moron who doesn't know  *how*!
Homer, furious, leaves the operating room. Edna lifts the girl's eyelids for Larch so that he can see how well unde the ether she is.
I wish you'd come to *me*, dear child.  You should have come to me, instead.
Homer storms down the hall, then stops, pulling off his w coat. Angry, pacing, he kicks at nothing.
Buster and Homer are digging the pit. Larch paces by the  coffin of the 12-year-old girl.
What'd she die of?
(inhales deeply) She died of *secrecy*, she died of  *ignorance*...
Buster nods, but he's totally bewildered.
(to Homer) If you expect people to be responsible  for their children, you have to give  them the right to decide whether or  not to *have* children. Wouldn't you  agree?
Buster doesn't get it. Homer has heard this too many time he rolls his eyes.
How about expecting people to be  responsible enough to control  themselves to begin with?
How about this child? You expect  *her* to be responsible?
Homer looks away.
I didn't mean her. I'm talking  about... adults. (annoyed) You know who I mean!
Larch studies him.

Buster is driving the old pickup truck, with the shovels a wheelbarrow in the back. Larch and Homer are in the cab they are being bounced all over the cab by Buster's wild  driving. Larch looks at Homer; he stares at him with a cu smile.
What?!
Larch says nothing. Homer gives him a look.
(smiling) It's just a marvel to me that you  still have such high expectations of  people.
I'm happy I amuse you.
(to Homer) Try to look at it this way. What  choice does Buster have? What are  his options? Nobody will ever adopt  him. (Buster considers  this)
Try to look at it *this* way. Buster  and I are sitting right here beside  you. We could have ended up in the  incinerator! (Buster grins)
Happy to be alive, under any  circumstances--is that your point?
Buster is distracted; he drives the truck into a ditch an it bounces around, missing a tree by an inch. He is up on the road again in a few seconds.
Happy to be alive... I guess so.

They are all distracted by a luxurious convertible that  overtakes them on the hill to the orphanage. The fast car driven by a handsome man in the uniform of the Army Air C a YOUNG OFFICER. From the passenger seat, a BEAUTIFUL YOU WOMAN smiles at them, rendering them speechless.

The luxurious convertible (now parked) has drawn all the  orphans to it. The handsome young officer (WALLY) and the beautiful young woman (CANDY) stand confused by the car;  they are surrounded by the curious orphans, with whom the are painfully self-conscious. They are overly friendly to the children as they are anxious of Larch and Homer and B (in their gravedigging attire), who are getting out of th truck. Nervously, Wally gives the children chocolates.
So many children. Are they all  orphans?
Well, this *is* an orphanage.
The kids climb into Wally's car.
Oh, they're getting into the car...  watch your fingers!
Curly tugs on Candy's dress, staring up at her, his face  already smeared with chocolate.
I'm the best.
(sweetly) You are?
(good with kids) The best? Wow! The best at *what*?
I'm the best one.
Curly's nose is streaming snot. Candy kneels beside him a holds her handkerchief to his nose.
Here, blow...
Curly tries to talk while she's holding his nose.
I really *am* the best, I just have  a cold.
Blow! There, I bet that feels better.
(sniffs) Yeah.
The other orphans are dying with envy--Candy is so beauti (Some, like Buster, are torn between Candy and the car.)
Curly, come here!
(to Larch) *Tell* them! I'm the one.
Virtually all the orphans have climbed into Wally's car.
(to Wally) I'm sorry. They're not used to seeing  a car like this.
It's okay--I don't mind.
Larch, scowling, presents himself to the new couple.
We brought some chocolates for the  kids.
(witheringly) Chocolates. How *thoughtful*.
Larch picks up Curly and carries him toward the boys'  division.
I'm the best! *Tell* them!
You're the best, Curly.
Homer is seated in the desk chair. The impressive couple in front of him.
So, Mrs...
Candy. Candy Kendall.
Wally jumps up to his feet to shake Homer's hand.
Wally. Wally Worthington.
Wally sits down. The three sit still for an awkward momen
(to Candy) How many months are you?
(whispers) Two.
Homer writes on a piece of paper. Candy and Wally exchang worried look.
So, now, uh... you're not... I mean,  do *you* do the--
No. Dr. Larch will be performing the  procedure.
(relieved) Ah, well... okay. Good! I just  wondered...
Edna pokes her head in the door.
Excuse me, Homer. Dr. Larch said  this one is your turn.
Edna quickly sees that all three of them have misundersto her.
Oh, dear--I'm sorry. I meant the  circumcision. That boy you delivered  on Tuesday...
Sure. Fine. Have you prepped him?
I'll get started.
Candy and Wally can't conceal how impressed they are with the young Homer.
Homer walks down the corridor, dressed in his operating g as the door to the O.R. opens and Wally stumbles out,  hurriedly opening a window. Wally breathes deeply to rega his composure.
I think it was the ether--the smell  got to me. (pause) God. This is all my fault.
Edna comes down the hall with a dirt-stained, crying Curl who's covering one eye.
(over the din) Steerforth got into the pantry--he's  eaten all the pie dough.
(sobbing) He wasn't sharing it, either.
He's down the hall, throwing up.
Homer nods to Edna, who is marching off with Curly. Wally smiles at Homer.
What kind of plane are you flying?
A B-24 Liberator.
Liberator...
Have you enlisted?
They wouldn't take me. I'm Class IV-- I've got a heart defect.
Really! Is it serious?
No, it's not serious. I'm just not  supposed to get excited. You know-- no strain, no stress. I try to keep  calm all the time.
Wally hears Homer's facetiousness--how tired he is of his heart condition.
Oh, well. I don't imagine there's  any strain or stress around *here*!

Homer appreciates the joke. The door to the operating room that Wally exited opens in the corridor; Candy is being wheeled out on a gurney by L and Angela. Wally rushes to Candy's side. Homer follows  slowly. Candy is groggy, coming out of the ether.
How is she doing?
Just fine.
(slurred speech) Boy or girl?
It was nothing--it's all over.
It's all over, honey.
They walk Candy on her gurney. Homer looks after them.
(slurred speech) I would like to have a baby, one  day. I really would.
Why, of course--you can have as many  children as you want. I'm sure you'll  have very beautiful children.
Larch wheels Candy behind a curtain.
You'll have Princes of Maine! You'll  have Kings of New England!
Larch has a different tone of voice when he speaks to Wal
I suggest you find yourself some  fresh air, Lieutenant.
Wally is left alone in the corridor.

Cranked at three-quarters, Fuzzy sits in bed, wheezing an coughing. He's drawing with great intensity, using crayon on a piece of paper held by a clipboard. Homer sits on th end of Fuzzy's bed, cleaning up Steerforth. Homer pauses look out of the window; he sees Wally, dashing and spotle in his uniform beside his flashy car. A life Homer might  have had crosses his face.
Homer, when is Halloween?
Homer turns to Fuzzy, who holds up his picture--a big pum with a jack-o-lantern face.
(distracted) Uh... it's the end of October.
Is that soon?
Homer looks at Fuzzy; his little body is working hard jus to breathe.
That's a few months away, Fuzz. (to Homer) I still don't feel so good.
(disappointed) Oh. It's the best time! How come we  only get pumpkins once a year?
Fuzzy coughs and coughs.
Don't get too excited, Fuzzy.
Why can't we have pumpkins for  Christmas, too? We don't get any  good presents at Christmas, anyway.
Homer looks out the window at Wally again. His decision f
Homer approaches the flashy car, where Wally is still pac
Has anyone offered you anything to  eat?
Actually, someone did. I just didn't  think I could eat anything.
An awkward silence, which Homer covers by examining the c
(trying to sound casual) I wonder if you might give me a ride.
Sure! Be glad to! Uh... a ride where?
(unprepared) Where are you going?
We're heading back to Cape Kenneth.
Homer nods, but he has no idea where Cape Kenneth is.
Cape Kenneth...
Wally nods.
That sounds fine.
Homer runs up the stairs, two steps at a time; he races i a corridor at full speed, exhilarated. Suddenly Dr. Larch appears in front of him. Homer stops abruptly, out of bre unable to speak.

As Homer stands guiltily, Larch rifles through an X-ray f holding various X rays up to the lit screen. He quickly f the one he's looking for, attaching it briefly to the scr for a confirming look--a heart X ray, which Larch waves a Homer as he talks.
(sarcastic) Doubtless you'll let me know what  immensely worthwhile or at least  *useful* thing it is that you find  to do.
(restrained) I wasn't intending to leave here in  order to be entirely useless--I expect  I'll find some ways to be of use.
In other parts of the world, I suppose  there are other ways.
(still restrained) Of course.

(blows up) Are you really so *stupid* that you  imagine you're going to find a more  gratifying life? What you're going  to find is people like the poor people  who get left here--only nobody takes  care of them as well! And you won't  be able to take care of them, either.  There's no taking care of *anybody*-- not out there!
(feeling trapped) You know I'm grateful for everything  you've done for me...
(calmly) I don't need your gratitude.
Larch hands Homer the heart X ray.
(exasperated) I don't need this--I know all about  my condition.
It's your heart--you ought to take  it with you.
Camera closes on Homer with the X ray.
Buster and Mary Agnes are serving the evening meal while  Larch rails at Angela and Edna, who are helping Buster an Mary Agnes. The sound of children in the dining hall is  intermittent and chaotic.
Going where? Does he have a plan of  some kind?
Will he be back soon?
I don't know! He's just leaving-- (to Angela) you're the one who says he needs to  see the world! (to Edna) *That's* what he'll do--he'll see  the world!
(stunned) He's leaving...
He'll need clothes... some money...
Let him try to *make* some money!  That's part of "seeing the world,"  isn't it?
(angrily) Oh, just stop it! You knew this was  going to happen. He's a young man.
(almost breaking) He's still a boy--out in the world,  he's still a boy.
Just find him some clothes, Wilbur.  He could use some clothes.
Camera closes on Larch, fighting tears.
Homer is packing his things--we see the heart X ray, and  some photos of Larch and Edna and Angela. Larch approaches Homer with a small bundle of clothes.
(gently, almost  reverently) I think these will fit you.

Homer is grateful and ashamed. Before he can speak, Edna there--a wad of bills in her hand. She tries to put the m in his pocket; when he refuses it, she simply puts the mo in his open suitcase, stuffing the bills under his clothe
You'll need some money--just a little  something, until you find a job.
Larch and Edna retreat from him, humbly, as if they were servants.

As Homer puts his stuff in the truck of Wally's car, Ange can't resist touching his face. She is too upset to speak From a window, Larch is watching the departure. He sees H saying goodbye to the children, embracing them. From another window, Fuzzy just stares. (Of course he's  coughing.) We see Wally carrying Candy to the car.
(groggy) I'm okay--I can walk.
I don't want you to walk--I want to  carry you. Should I put the top up?  It might get cold.
No--keep it down. I want to feel the  air.
She speaks to Homer, touching his sleeve, like a sleepy  person, as Wally puts her gently in the backseat.
(still groggy) Coming with us? It's always a good  idea to have a doctor along for the  ride.

Homer gets in the passenger seat beside Wally, who starts the car; suddenly there is Curly. Homer can't look at Cur who looks betrayed. Edna picks up Curly and carries him t the passenger-side window. Curly is sobbing.
I have to go, Curly. I'm sorry. (to Edna) I couldn't find Buster. Will you  tell him...
He can't finish what he has to say. Edna kisses him good- bye. From the window, Larch watches the car leave. Buster, whittling a stick, isn't watching.

There is quiet as the journey gets underway. Wally keeps  glancing at Candy in the rear-view mirror; she seems dist lost in thought. Homer is taking everything in--the speed the road, the wind in his face.
Angela speaks to the boys.
Let us be happy for Homer Wells...

In the girls' washroom, in front of the mirror by the row sinks, Mary Agnes is repeatedly slapping her face. Angela benediction to the boys plays Over this scene of violent  self-abuse. Except for the sound of the slaps. Mary Agnes doesn't make a sound.
Homer Wells has found a family. Good  night, Homer!
Good night, Homer!
On his bed, Larch is taking ether. We hear the refrain fr the boys in the bunk room Over.
Good night, Homer! Good night, Homer!  Good night, Homer Wells!
The radio is playing. Candy is lying down, her knees draw up, in the backseat; she appears to be asleep, oblivious Homer and Wally's conversation.

Actually, the Army has given me leave  twice. First when my father died,  and now I'm on leave to help my mother-- I'm just trying to get her ready for  the harvest. She's no farmer. Apples  were my dad's business. And with the  war on, she's short on pickers.
Candy's eyes are open but her voice is groggy.
(to Homer) Wally thinks apples are boring.
(to Homer) I never said they were boring.
You said, "Apples aren't exactly  flying."
Well, they aren't.
Homer looks back at Candy. Her eyes close.
I think I'd probably like the apple  business.
You're a little overqualified, aren't  you?
No, I'm not. I need a job.
The only jobs are picking jobs.  Picking apples is truly boring.
Candy's eyes snap open and she sits up a little.
There! You said it was boring.
Well, *picking* them is! It's about  as exciting as... walking!
Candy seems irritated with Wally. Homer tries to engage h
Is your family in the apple business,  too?
No, but I work there--I like it. My  dad's a lobsterman.
I've never seen a lobster.
Really?
I've never seen the ocean, either.
(amazed) You've never seen the *ocean*?
Homer shakes his head, smiles.
That's not funny... that's *serious*.

The car is parked at the side of the road. Wally is half- hidden behind a tree. Candy and Homer are left alone in t car; there's an awkward silence as Homer pretends not to  hear Wally's excessive peeing. Suddenly Candy starts to s
I couldn't have a baby with someone  who's leaving me--I didn't know what  else to do!
Homer is a doctor--he's used to postabortion reactions.
I know.
He's going to be dropping bombs on  Mandalay! They're going to be shooting  at him!
Where's Mandalay?
Burma!
Oh...
I can't have a baby alone. I don't  even know if he's coming back!
I understand.
He doesn't, really. Wally returns. Wally leans over Candy hug her.
Honey, honey... of course I'll come  back.
Candy pounds on his chest with her fists.
You don't *know*, Wally. You have no  *idea*!
Wally backs away. Candy sobs uncontrollably.
Stay away from me!
Wally signals to Homer to get out of the car. Later, Wally and Homer stand outside the car, overhearing Candy's weeping. Homer is smoking nervously.
(strictly medical) This is all normal. Don't worry. The  abortion procedure... it affects  you. It's the ether, too. It'll take  a little time.
I don't *have* any time. There's a  *war*!
It's all very normal.
Wally looks at Homer, who takes a nervous drag on his  cigarette.
You ought to cut that shit out--it's  terrible for you.
Homer looks at Wally; he sees the authority in his eyes.  Homer drops his cigarette and puts it out with his foot. They notice that Candy has stopped crying. Wally finds Ca asleep in the backseat.
The lone car on the road. Snatches of war news from the r are the only sound as the headlights illuminate the dark  highway.

The car is parked, with Homer sleeping in it alone. The s of the ocean increase as Homer opens his eyes. Homer gets out of the car and walks toward the beach, enchanted. The it is: his first view ever of an ocean, the horizon, the glimmering on the water. Candy is lying on a blanket in t sand. Wally is throwing rocks in the water. Homer takes i all in. When Candy calls for him, Homer walks up to her.
I'm a little worried about the... (she gestures below  her waist) ...about how much bleeding is okay.
It should taper off tomorrow, but it  can come back again. You have cramps? (Candy nods) They'll ease up, almost entirely. As  long as the bleeding isn't heavy,  it's normal.
Catch!
A football comes flying through the air toward Homer; it  bounces off his chest. Wally laughs.
(meaning the football) Give it here!
Homer throws the football; it's clear he's never thrown o before.
What was *that*?! Come over here!

Homer runs over to Wally, who proceeds to show him how to pass the ball. Snatches of his instruction drift to Candy who closes her eyes. "Put your fingers on the laces--no, rests in your palm, like this! You want the laces up--yes like that!"
Homer and Wally sit on the beach a short distance from Ca blanket. She appears to be asleep. Wally looks in her  direction before he speaks to Homer.
It's called the Burma run. It's about  a seven-hour round-trip flight between  India and China.
Wally draws a crude map in the sand.
"Burma run" because you fly over  Burma...
*And* over the Himalayas. That's  called flying over the hump.
On Candy's face: she's not asleep; she's listening.
At what altitude?
I've got thirty-five minutes to climb  to fifteen thousand feet--that's the  first mountain pass.
Homer looks at Wally, thoughtfully.
What lousy luck--I mean your orders...  to draw an assignment like that!
(conspiratorially) Actually, I volunteered.
Homer is shocked; he looks back at Candy, lowers his voic
It's the flying, right? You love to  fly, don't you?
Wally nods; he also gives a look in Candy's direction bef he responds.
I love the bombing, too. But there's  also the Himalayas--they have the  most wicked air currents in the world.  I wouldn't miss flying there for  anything.
Homer's smile suggests that he's impressed, but that he  wouldn't have Wally's enthusiasm for the task. Wally laug and puts his hand on Homer's shoulder.
Uh, look... if you're serious about  wanting a job, picking apples isn't  that boring.
Oh, I would love that, Wally.
The car is parked at a lobster pound. Homer sits in the c watching Wally carrying Candy's bag to the door. Candy st outside the car; she shakes Homer's hand.
I guess I'll see you around the  orchards. Thanks for everything.
Sure... I'll see you around.

Candy turns and heads toward the house to catch up with W A lobsterman in his boat is approaching the dock. It's RA Candy's father. Candy waves. "Hi, Daddy!" Homer glances a Candy and Wally on the dock, kissing good-bye.
(whispering) I love you, Wally.
I love you, too. See you tomorrow.
Wally drives up to the Worthington house; he gets out of car. Homer sits in the car, admiring the beautiful farmho
Come on. You have to meet my mom. (conspiratorially) If it comes up, I've been at a  wedding. That's where I met you, at  the wedding.
Homer as never seen such a room: the sports trophies, the photos of athletic teams, and of Candy with Wally. Model  airplanes are everywhere. Mrs. Worthington's voice comes  from the hall.
Wally? I expected you earlier...
She appears in the doorway of Wally's room. Mrs. Worthing (OLIVE) is an elegant, fiftyish New Englander, as handsom as Wally, but more reserved. She is surprised to see Home
This is Homer Wells--he's the most  overqualified apple picker you'll  ever meet, but he's dying to learn  the apple business.
Wally is taking his uniform off as he speaks, just droppi it on the floor as he quickly puts on some farm clothes.
How do you do, Homer Wells...
Homer has never met anyone like her.
How do you do...
Mrs. Worthington starts picking up her son's uniform from the floor. She is politely curious about Homer.
Were you a friend of the bride or  the groom?
Homer looks confused; he seems to have forgotten about th alleged wedding. Wally puts his arm around Homer, urging into the hall.
Homer is everybody's friend, Mom...  the bride's, the groom's, mine,  Candy's, *everybody's*.
Homer is embarrassed, but Olive is obdurately well-manner
Well, perhaps you'll come to dinner,  Homer...
Wally calls to her as he pushes Homer down the hall.
Not tonight, Mom--he's got to meet  *Mr. Rose*!

Homer and Wally get out of the jeep at the cider house, a barnlike building with adjacent sheds and, behind it, lin after line of trees--the apple orchards. Homer sees an outdoor shower where THREE BLACK MEN are  showering. It is a wooden stall that leaves the shower's  occupants visible above and below their midsections. A FO BLACK MAN is caught naked, running behind the cider house and out of sight as he wraps a towel around himself.
You already used up the hot water!
You're usin' my soap, ain't you?
I ain't usin' no soap--it's too cold  to bother with soap!
There ain't never enough hot water,  soap or no soap.
They're migrants.
(no clue) Migrants?
Yes. They pick fruit, all kinds.  They travel up and down the coast  with the seasons. (leaning close to  Homer) The trick to Mr. Rose is, you have  to let him be the boss.

Homer wonders what that means as Wally reaches for the do of the cider house. Before Wally can knock, a pretty youn black girl, ROSE ROSE, bumps open the screen door with he hip and throws a bucket of water in the grass--almost hit Homer and Wally.
That sink's backed up again, Wally.  I thought you was gonna get me a  plumber.
Rose, this is Homer--Homer, this is  Mr. Rose's daughter, Rose.
Rose Rose?
Pretty, ain't it? You a plumber?
No, no--Homer is a new *picker*.  He's going to stay here with you.
This gets the attention of the men on their way from the  showers. They walk over, towels around their waists.
(suspiciously) He's stayin' *here*?
The screen door swings open and shut again, startling the all, as MR. ROSE comes out of the cider house.
That daughter of mine sure is Miss  Hospitality, ain't she, Wally?
Grinning, Mr. Rose shakes Wally's hand. Rose Rose goes ba inside the cider house as Mr. Rose shakes Homer's hand. H introduces himself.
You got lots of experience pickin',  I suppose.
Homer's got no experience, Arthur,  but he's smarter then I am. He's a  fast learner.
Mr. Rose looks briefly at the men, who wait for his react
This is history. Ain't that what  you're sayin', Wally? I guess we  makin' *history*... havin' this young  man stay with us!
Wally slaps Homer on the back; he goes inside the cider h to help Rose Rose with the plumbing.
(over his shoulder) See you later.
Homer looks at Mr. Rose for instructions. Mr. Rose stares back at him with his enigmatic smile.
So. What should I do now?
Out back, there's a shed. It's just  a mess. If that shed was better  organized, I could put my truck in  there.
Homer looks at Mr. Rose with an uncomprehending expressio
If you're as smart as Wally says,  you know you sometimes gotta do one  job before you do another.
Homer thinks that over. Later, Homer is cleaning out the shed.

The pickers all sit down to supper around a picnic table. Homer with Mr. Rose, Rose Rose, and the other black picke Mr. Rose takes an apple from a bowl on the table. Then he pulls out a knife and opens it in one fluid motion; he's fast, the knife seems to come out of nowhere. He begins t peel the apple. Homer eyes Mr. Rose, but Mr. Rose's focus riveted to his apple and the long, perfect strand of peel dangling from it.
You did a good job with that shed,  Homer.
Peaches breaks the awkward silence.
What kind of a name is Homer?
It's the name of a cat. Originally.  Well, not *originally*.
Homer decides to stop. Another silence.

Now, now--we all got names, sensible  or not. (to Homer) Peaches is from Georgia, where we  met him pickin' peaches. He's still  better with peaches than hs is with  apples. (Peaches grins) Jack here is new. And this here is  Hero, 'cause he was a hero of some  kind or other once. Ain't that right,  Hero?
There are some disrespectful suggestions from the pickers concerning what his heroism might have been.
And this here sensitive-lookin' fella  is Muddy. The less said about Muddy,  the better. Ain't that right, Muddy?
Muddy scowls at Homer, but he smiles at Mr. Rose.

Homer unpacks his suitcase. (His bed should be nearest Mu and Mr. Rose's.) Jack lies on his bed, smoking. Muddy, al smoking, is sitting on his bed, sharpening a knife. Hero Peaches are playing cards on one of their beds. Mr. Rose finishing shaving. Rose Rose watches Homer unpack.
What's that?
It's just my heart.
What you got a picture of your heart  for?
He holds up the X ray, in order to show her.
There's a little something wrong  with it. Just this part here--the  right ventricle. It's slightly  enlarged.
So what?
Yes, so what. It's nothing serious,  really. Just a small defect.
It's big enough to keep you out of  the war, I suppose. Ain't that right?
Right.
Rose Rose picks up the book that Homer has put on the bed She studies the cover; it's "Great Expectations" by Charl Dickens. She puts it down, restlessly.
They told me I was too old to serve.
They told Muddy his feet was too  flat!
Everybody laughs, except Muddy.
(to Peaches) And you was "generally unfit," as I  recall.
Finished unpacking, Homer sits on his bed; he picks up "G Expectations" and begins to read. Rose Rose sits down nex to him, watching him read. Homer notices her interest.
Do you like to read?
(embarrassed) I can't read. Nobody taught me.
Homer smiles politely and goes back to his book. Rose Ros keeps looking over his shoulder at the pages.
(pointing to the page) What does it say there?
Homer looks around at the pickers lying in their beds,  smoking, listening. (Like bedtime stories at the orphanag he thinks; however, the picker's attitude is suspicious,  reserved.)
(reading) "I looked at the stars, and considered  how awful it would be for a man to  turn his face to them as he froze to  death, and see no help or pity in  all the glittering multitude."
Homer looks up; there's no response.
(to Rose Rose) More?

Some muttering, some giggling, mostly silence. Rose Rose  wants more, but suddenly Jack jumps out of bed and stomps the kitchen end of the cider house, where a piece of pape is tacked to the wall. Jack is talking to Homer all the w
Since you're the one who's smart  enough to read... what's this?
Jack points at the piece of paper. Homer gets up and look at it.
It's a list of rules, it seems.
All the men groan--Jack swears and Peaches laughs.
*Whose* rules?
They're for us, I suppose.
Go on and read 'em, Homer.
"One. Please don't smoke in bed."
It's too late for that one!
All the smokers laugh and cough in their beds.
(uncharacteristically  blunt) Stop it, Homer. They aren't our rules.  We didn't write them. I don't see no  reason to read them.
Okay...
Rose Rose stomps back to her bed. Her father absently sna his towel.
Everybody is asleep, except Homer. He is staring at the  ceiling in the quiet semi-darkness, the book lying on his chest.
(distant echoing) Good night, you Princes of Maine!  You Kings of New England.
Dr. Larch is standing in the doorway to the boys' room; h closes the door.
Homer, on his bed, closes his eyes.
Larch lies in bed with his eyes open. (No ether.)
The cider house and the apple orchard in the moonlight.
Wally in his farm clothes at the wheel of the Jeep--he is racing through the orchards, dodging trees, with Homer in the passenger seat, hanging on for dear life.
Remember this! In the morning, when  the tall grass is wet, you can make  the Jeep slide on the grass. Can you  feel it?
Homer is excited as Wally weaves among the trees--faster faster.
It's almost like flying.
What about the trees?
The trees are flak--antiaircraft  fire from those geeks on the ground.
Wally brakes hard. The Jeep comes to a stop in the packin house area. Candy has been waiting on the loading platform. The picke are working in the background.
(defensively to Candy) I was just showing Homer the  orchards... kind of a geography  lesson.
(good-naturedly) I know what you've been doing.
She pulls an apple branch, with an apple to two, out of t vehicle's grille--or else the branch is wedged in the fro bumper or headlight area. Candy playfully starts poking W with the branch.
(to Wally) You've been giving him a *flying*  lesson!
(teasing her) He *loved* it! (to Homer) Didn't you?
Yeah, it was great.
Wally gets the apple branch away from Candy. He pins her  arms at her sides--he hugs her, kisses her. She doesn't  struggle.
(laughing to Homer) He thinks people *like* to get whacked  by branches.
*Homer* liked it! (to Homer) Didn't you?
Yeah, sure. There's no stress or  strain around here...
They all laugh. Homer observes the happy couple.
Homer is walking with Wally and Candy. The orchards are  beautiful.
Much activity: the pickers are unloading apple crates fro full flatbed trailer. An angry-looking VERNON gives Homer evil glare. Homer spills some apples lifting the crate to the loading platform.
What's wrong with you?
Mr. Rose takes Homer aside.
That's Vernon. You best stay away  from him until he gets to know you  better--then you best stay away from  him *more*!
Wally, in full uniform, appears from inside the packing h he calls for Homer.
Out lieutenant's calling you, Homer.  Mind your ass.
Homer smiles are runs toward Wally.
Homer and Wally walk through the packing house, where the HEFTY, LOUD WOMEN sort through the apples rolling by on t conveyor tracks. Wally snatches an apple from one of them giving it to Homer.
(to Homer) You getting along okay?
Before Homer can answer, the women interrupt.
Where is that Candy?
Did she leave you, Wally?
Who's the boy?
Wally makes an effort to introduce Homer, but he's  interrupted.
Wally, you can marry Debra if Candy  leaves you!
Wally's gonna marry *me* if Candy  leaves him!
You can marry all three of us, Wally!
We can take turns.
Wally puts his hand to his heart.
You girls make it hard for a guy to  go off to war. (points to Homer) But I'll leave my best man here to  pinch-hit for me.
As the women are left behind giggling, Wally continues ta to Homer.

Uh... I'm shipping out sooner than I  thought. I just wanted to be sure  you were settled in--and happy enough,  considering... (grabbing another  apple from a crate) Are you bored stiff? Or can you stick  it out for a bit?
Uh... actually, picking apples is as  much excitement as I want for a while.  I'm grateful for the job.
(his hand on Homer's  shoulder) You're the one who's helping *me*,  Homer. You're going to give my mom a  little peace of mind while I'm gone.  Candy, too.
Well, sure... that's good, then. (awkward pause) All I mean is, I'm lucky I met you.
I don't think so, Homer. *I'm* the  lucky one.
Homer shakes his head. Wally stops walking; they both sto
(more serious) You want to fight about it?

Homer is unfamiliar with this kind of kidding around; at  first he is startled, but then he laughs. Wally laughs, t They shake hands. Mr. Rose calls out to Homer from the tractor. The pickers are impatiently waiting for him on the flatbed; they're g back to the orchard. Homer has to run to catch up to them He jumps on the flatbed; he sees Wally waving good-bye.

High up in a tall tree on a couple of ladders, Mr. Rose a Homer are picking side by side. Mr. Rose is picking with  high-speed perfection, but Homer is slower and fumbling-- drops an occasional apple to the ground.

You pickin' more cider apples then  anythin' else. Them drops is good  only for cider. And you pickin' the  stems with the apples only half the  time. They good only for cider, too-- if you don't pick them stems. (Homer watches him) The rule is, you wanna pick the apple  *with* the stem, Homer. And see  here... see that *bud* that's just  above the stem? That's the bud for  *next year's* apple--that's called  the *spur*. You pick the spur, you  pickin' two years in one--you pickin'  next year's apple 'fore it have a  chance to grow. You leave that on  the branch, you hear?
Homer nods; he picks more carefully, with more concentrat
(approvingly) That's better. I can tell you got  yourself some education. Them's good  hands you got, Homer. Them hands you  got, they know what they're doin'-- ain't that right?
I guess so...

Homer can see over the apple mart parking lot from the to of the tree. He can see the driveway of the Worthington h where Candy and Olive are saying a tearful good-bye to Wa Distracted, Homer drops another couple of apples, which M Rose observes with a wry smile.
Wilbur! Wilbur!
Larch is doing something at his desk when Angela comes in
Wilbur, you should read this.
Larch stares at Angela, who holds a letter.
It's from the Board. Another letter.
Dr. Larch stands in front of a mechanical drawing easel. works intently with a calligraphic pen, but we don't see  what he's working on. Angela and Edna sit at the desk; th looking over the letter.

(quoting the letter) Uh... "merely suggesting that some  new blood might benefit you all...  someone with new ideas in the  obstetrical and pediatric fields." (she looks up at Larch) I think they're just testing some  ideas for our next meeting.
Dr. Holtz seems nice. I think he  only wants to help...
He is a goddamn psychiatrist--of  *course* he wants to "help"! He'd be  happy if he could help *commit* me!
It's that Mrs. Goodhall you have to  be careful of, Wilbur.
One has to be more than "careful" of  Mrs. Goodhall--she has sufficient  Christian zeal to start her own  country! I'd like to give her a little  ether.
So what are you going to do?

Larch puts down the pen, comes around the easel, opens a  drawer in a filing cabinet, and hands Edna a folder conta a few cleanly typed pages. Larch returns to the easel, to his painstaking work. Edna opens the file; as she and Ang read the contents, Larch recites from memory as he works.
"Homer Wells, born Portland, Maine,  March 2, 1915..."
Homer was born *here*, in, what was  it, 1922?
"...graduated Bowdoin College, 1935,  and Harvard School of Medicine, 1939."
This is *your* life story, Wilbur!  You just changed the dates!

"An internship and two years of  training at the Boston Lying-in,  South End Branch. For his age, he  was judged an accomplished  gynecological obstetrical surgeon;  he is also experienced in pediatric  care..."
You *invented* him! You've completely  made his up!
Don't you understand? The board is  going to *replace* me! That's what  the "new blood" is *for*!
You mean they'll replace you with  someone who won't perform abortions.
(sarcastically) Well, we can only guess about that,  Edna. They *are* against the law.
These *credentials* are against the  law!
We all know who trained Homer--his  credentials are as good as mine are.  Don't you be holy to me about the  *law*! What has the law done for any  of us here?
Edna and Angela think this over.
(points at file) So here is my candidate. What do you  think?
But what about school records? Homer  doesn't have any *diplomas*...
Larch turns the easel around. Attached is a parchment hea "HARVARD MEDICAL SCHOOL"--it's a diploma-in-progress.
He *will* have them, Edna.
The women are shocked, awed.
Oh, Wilbur, I don't know... (sudden thought) We don't even know where he is!
Where's that Homer?
Homer stands in front of a ladder that leans against the  cider house; he starts to climb up, drawn by the murmurin voices, the soft laughter.
Who cares?
Now, now. He's a good boy.
Shit. We don't know what he is.
Jack, you gotta watch your language  'round my daughter.
Homer arrives at the top and sees everyone sitting on a l plank, a bench attached to the apex of the roof--obviousl popular spot.
Here he is.
No one moves.
Where's your manners? Make room for  Homer, so's he can enjoy the view.
What view?
Peaches slides over and Homer sits down.
Are we supposed to be up here? The  rules said...
Homer, you the only one who's read  them rules, so you the only one who  feels like he's doin' somethin' wrong.
The others laugh.
*What* view?
Well, Muddy, we can look at all these  angry stars Homer's been readin' to  us about.
More laughter; Homer smiles, enjoying the teasing.
(gesturing toward the  Worthington farmhouse) I bet the view looks better from the  Worthin'tons'.
You think so, Jack? Well... I wouldn't  want to be in that Wally's shoes  tonight.
(playfully, teasing  him) Daddy, I'd like to be in that Wally's  shoes *every* night.
(teasing her back) You lucky you in your work boots  tonight, girl...
What's lucky about that?
Rose Rose is being physically affectionate with her fathe lightly punching his arm, rubbing the top of his head.
You know where that Wally is tonight,  darlin'? He's up there in them angry  stars. (gesturing at the  dark sky) He's flyin' all around up there...  with them Japs shooting at him.
They all look up, imagining that. Homer more than the oth Rose Rose, looking thoughtful, rests her head on her fath shoulder. They are completely natural together.
Homer and the pickers are loading crates of apples into a shipping truck. Olive and Candy are consulting some paper (the shipping tally) on a clipboard; Mr. Rose is standing beside them.
They all on board, Mrs. Worthin'ton.
Thank you, Arthur. (see is looking at  Homer) And how is our Homer working out?
She catches Homer's eye; he smiles, then joins them. Mr.  Rose puts his arm around him.
Oh, he's a smart young man, most of  the time--Wally was right about him.
Olive is looking over the rest of the picking crew.
No rotten apples?
(it's an old way of  speaking that they  have) No, no--not this year. Well... maybe  we got *one*, but it ain't Homer.
He means Jack, who gives Olive and Candy and Mr. Rose a  furtive look. Olive smiles at Rose Rose, who comes up to and Candy. Olive touches Rose Rose with affection.
Rose... dear girl, I'm sure I can  find you some other clothes. (to Candy) You must have some things that would  fit her.
Candy takes Rose Rose by the shoulders and turns her arou Rose Rose is enjoying this.
I have a *ton* of things that would  fit you.
Now, now, Candy--this girl don't  need no more clothes, not for pickin'.
He starts leading his daughter away.
(charming) Arthur, there's no such thing as a  young woman who's got all the clothes  she needs.
Olive waves good-bye as she moves toward her car. Candy t to Homer.
So. Not bored yet?
I'm *never* bored! It's all very...  different for me... here.
Homer has the hardest time looking at Candy.
Uh... have you been *feeling* okay?

When I'm not thinking about Wally.  I'm not good at being alone. (realizing) Oh, goodness. You meant... yes, I'm  fine. I... (struggling to change  the subject) ...I don't suppose you've seen a  lobster yet.
Homer shakes his head. He looks at the tractor and the em trailer. Mr. Rose and the pickers are just watching them.
(more seriously) You have to come to my dad's lobster  pound and see one, then.
Okay...
Homer looks toward the pickers sitting on the flatbed whe he hears the tractor start. Candy follows his gaze.
I better go.
I don't think Mr. Rose would leave  without you.
Mr. Rose gestures for Muddy to drive off; the tractor tra pulls away.
(laughing) Sorry!
Homer has to run to catch up.
(calling) Come next week!
He jumps on the back of the departing flatbed between Mr. Rose and Rose Rose, as Candy watches him.

An anxious-looking WHITE PLUMBER is fixing the kitchen si while the pickers (in their towels) stand around and watc Homer is putting on his best shirt. Peaches admires the s as Rose Rose cooks the night's supper on the wood stove.
Whoa--look at that Homer! He's gettin'  all dressed up for supper tonight!
He ain't gettin' dressed to have  supper with *us*, Peaches!
The pickers all look at Homer, who looks guilty as he lea
(to the plumber) Don't let us make you nervous or  nothin'--we know you gotta job to  do.
Yeah, we can wait all night for the  water to come back on--you just go  on and take your time.
Homer pedals a bicycle down a dirt road.
Ray holds a lobster up to the camera. We see the old-fash wooden pens, floating dockside.
Hungry?
Homer looks uncertain.
Homer and Ray and Candy go up the gangplank from the dock the lobster pound.
They're the garbage-eaters of the  ocean's floor. The seagulls clean up  the shore. The lobsters clean up the  bottom of the sea.
They eat everything?
Everything that falls to the bottom.
It's time somebody ate *them*.
(to Candy) I was lookin' for Wally's letter. I  was gonna show it to Homer... (to Homer) They made him a captain already-- *Captain* Worthington!
Daddy, it's a letter to *me*.
He mentions Homer, too, you know.
(awkwardly) Wally said to say, "Hello."
(equally awkward) Oh! That's... nice.
(to Homer) Wally said the most spectacular hits  were in the oil fields at Yenangyat.
Later, through the window of the lobster pound, we see th eating lobster around a kitchen table. Laughter and some  unclear dialogue drift to us.

With the bicycle stowed in the trunk, Candy is driving Ho back to the cider house. They pass a drive-in movie theat the marquee announcing "CLOSED FOR THE SEASON." Homer sta in awe at the giant blank screen.
A movie *outside*?
Yes. But it's closed all the time  now, because of the blackout.
People watched the movies in their  cars?
(smiling) When they watched at all. Do you  like movies?
Yes! I've only seen one, though.
Candy looks at him; he isn't joking.
You've seen only one movie? Which  one?
"King Kong". It's really good.
Candy laughs.
I haven't seen "King Kong" since I  was a kid!
Homer laughs a little self-consciously; around her, he fe like he's *still* a kid.

At one table, the children are happily eating apples; a f of the kids are stuffing apples from a big bowl into thei pockets. At another table, Larch, Edna, and Angela sit ar an open packing crate of apples. Larch takes a bite from apple and spits it out. Angela takes the apple out of his hand.
That's a pie apple, Wilbur. Homer  said you're not supposed to eat it!
Angela hands him another apple.
So he's an apple expert, is he?
Angela gives him a critical look as Larch takes a bite ou of the new apple.
(sarcastically) Oh my, yes! This is a *far* superior  taste--and crisp, too! You know, so  many apples are disappointingly mealy.  I wonder of most of the apples in my  life weren't meant for pies!
Wilbur, he picked them for us  himself...
(incredulous) You don't find it depressing that  Homer Wells is picking apples?
Both Edna and Angela glower at him.
Or that he can't be bothered to write  us a proper letter? A dissertation  on apples, we don't need!
(annoyed) He probably doesn't make much money  picking apples--he must have had to  pay to send them, too.
I wouldn't worry, Edna, that he  doesn't have money. If he gets hungry,  he can pick his dinner!
Larch angrily tosses the half-eaten apple into the garbag
Wilbur, it's a *gift*! How can you  be angry with Homer for sending us a  *gift*?
Larch stares into space, depressed. Then he examines the  crate and finds the mailing label that says "OCEAN VIEW  ORCHARDS--CAPE KENNETH, MAINE." He rips it off, holds it triumphantly.
I'll show him a *gift*! I'll give  him a gift he can *use*!
Larch storms out of the room.

A newsreel from the war is playing on the screen--soldier marching, smiling, waving to the camera. Homer and Candy together watching. Homer is completely fascinated; Candy  watches Homer as much as the news. Her expression changes when the newsreel cuts to footage from an air raid.
Candy and Homer walk out of the theatre, under the marque and past the poster for "Wuthering Heights."
(disappointed) But you looked as if you liked it.
(smiling) I *did* like it. All I said was,  "It's not 'King Kong'."
Candy makes a face, but in good fun.
First she loved him, then she didn't,  then no one else could have him...
She *did* love him! (teasing him) How many women have you known?
Homer is embarrassed; he ducks the question.
And what did she die of, exactly?
She was torn apart! She died of a  broken heart.
Oh, sure!
Homer smiles and shakes his head; Candy starts to laugh.
What's the *medical* explanation?
Well, she was in a weakened  condition... (laughs) I don't know! What about "King Kong"?!  Is that medically possible?
Homer smiles; he knows she's teasing him, and he likes it
(mock serious) At least King Kong knew what he  *wanted*.
Candy pushes him playfully. They're both having a good ti *too* good a time.

Homer is picking apples in a big tree; Rose Rose is on a  ladder in the tree right beside him. She's picking about  twice as fast as he is, and he keeps dropping his apples. another tree, Muddy is watching.
What is you *doin'* with that Candy,  Homer?
(imitating Mr. Rose) He's makin' history, I suppose.
From the surrounding trees, the other pickers laugh.
You ain't gettin' in no trouble, I  hope.
No trouble.
In adjacent trees, both Peaches and Hero are picking appl they can hear Homer and Rose Rose, too. (So can Mr. Rose.
That Candy--she's the nicest girl I  know!
She's about the most beautiful girl  I ever seen--I don't know if she's  the nicest.
She's the nicest *and* the most  beautiful girl I've ever known.
The men *oooh* and *aaah* at Homer's announcement--Mr. Ro too.
That sounds like you is in trouble  already, Homer.
That's right--that sounds like trouble  to me.
I'm not in trouble.
Yeah, you is. I know when people is  in trouble, and you is.
Camera closes on Homer's face; he keeps picking.
His name is Homer Wells...

Edna and Angela face the Board of Trustees around a table Larch circles the table as everyone reads the contents of folder. Larch has provided a copy for each member. The th elderly gentlemen on the Board don't speak; they just nod their heads to everything Dr. Holtz or Mrs. Goodhall says
...and his *pathetic* resume is the  best I've seen. Though I find it  hard to believe the Board would be  interested in this character.
But he looks like an excellent young  man, a first-rate candidate!
He looks like a bleeding-heart  missionary *moron* to me, but that's  going to be the problem with any  doctor interested in coming here!
Do you know him?
*No*! I don't want to know him! He's  doing *missionary* work--in *India*!  I wrote him *weeks* ago, but he's  either too holy or too busy to answer.  Maybe he got killed in the war!

Suddenly Steerforth bursts through the door, having been  pushed from behind by Mary Agnes. The two stop when they what's going on--not to mention Larch's stern expression. They back out. Mary Agnes winking at Dr. Holtz before the door closes. Mrs. Goodhall is ready to continue.

I fail to see how someone courageous  enough to make a commitment to a  foreign mission is automatically to  be dismissed--that part of the world  requires precisely the kind of  dedication that is needed here.
Does it *snow* in Bombay? One winter  here and we'll be shipping him south,  in a *coffin*!

You can't think that a man who has  *served* under such conditions as  exist over there will be in the  slightest daunted by a little *snow*-- have you no idea how harsh and  primitive and full of *disease* that  part of the world is?
Then I suppose we can look forward  to catching various diseases from  him!
But, Dr. Larch, he seems exceptionally  qualified...
I'm not talking about his medical  qualifications. It's the *Christian*  thing that bothers me--I just don't  see it being of much *use* around  here.
(bitterly) I fail to see how a little  Christianity could *hurt* anyone  here!
Anyway, I was just showing you this  guy as an example of what's available-- I didn't think you'd be interested.
We're *very* interested!
Yes, *very*!
You wouldn't be opposed to meeting  with him?
I suppose it wouldn't hurt to *meet*  him. What's his name again?
Dr. Homer Wells.
(mumbling) I just hope he won't expect us to  say *Grace* all the time.
The three elderly gentlemen repeat the name.
It's a nice name, very New England.
Very *Maine*, a very *local*-sounding  name.
*Very*!
A song plays on the old phonograph as a happy Larch and A dance. Edna interrupts them.
I just wanted to ask you...
Edna! Come dance with me! Let's be  foolish tonight.
Does he *know* he's supposed to be  in India? Does he even *want* to  come back?
This causes Larch to take the needle off the record.
(angrily) He's a field hand! What could possibly  hold him there?
The rain beats down on Olive's car. Homer gets soaking we as he leans in to talk to Candy, who's behind the wheel. Rose calls to Homer from the doorway of the mill room.

Mr. Rose is instructing Homer as they stand bottling cide in their yellow slickers and rubber boots. Rose Rose is h down the pressboards; Muddy and Hero and Peaches are oper the grinder and the press. Jack is stirring the vat. In a defiant, contemptuous way, Jack keeps flicking the ash of his cigarette into the vat. This make everyone uncomforta only Mr. Rose doesn't appear to notice.

Cider don't have no taste till later  in October--it's too watery now,  when we're usin' just them early  Macs and them Gravensteins. You don't  get no *good* cider till you're  pickin' them Golden Delicious and  them Winter Bananas, them Baldwins  and them Russerts...
What about the worms? Most of these  apples are the drops--off the ground,  right? There have to be worms.
Of *course* there's worms, Homer!  And what is them worms, really? They  just *protein*, them worms! They is  *good* for you!
Everyone but Jack laughs. He takes a last drag on his  cigarette, then deliberately drops it into the vat.
That just ain't right, Jack--your  cigarette's gonna end up in nine or  ten gallons of this batch of cider!  That ain't right.
Them people drinkin' that cider,  they don't know there's a cigarette  in there!
It's not that hard to find it in  there, Jack--it'll take you just a  minute. You just gotta go fishin'.
You mean *swimmin'*. I ain't goin'  in that vat to fish out no cigarette!
What business is you in, Jack? Just  tell me what your business is...
Jack looks for a translation from the other men, who are  nervous.
Just say you're in the *apple*  business, man. That's the only  business you wanna be in. Just say  it.
Jack pulls a knife on Mr. Rose.
(whispers excitedly  to Jack) You don't wanna go in the knife  business with Mistuh Rose--just say  you're in the *apple* business, Jack!
(to Mr. Rose) What business are *you* in?

We never see Mr. Rose's knife. We see the men circle each other: Jack takes a swipe at Mr. Rose's head--then he ste back, his yellow slicker slashed open. His slicker is ope up, right up the middle. His shirt underneath the slicker slashed open, too--he feels his bare chest and stomach,  feeling for the cut. But there's no cut--Jack's not bleed he's not even scratched. Just his clothes have been slash
I'm in the *knife* business, Jack.  You don't wanna go in the knife  business with me.
