Muddy turns Jack around and views his slashed clothes.
You're lucky he didn't cut your  *nipples* off, man.
The good news, Jack, is you're half- undressed for *swimmin'*...
Yeah, that cigarette ain't hard to  find when you're properly undressed.
Jack starts to undress for the vat. Mr. Rose ushers Homer and Rose Rose outside.

Mr. Rose has cut his own hand in the fight. Homer's  professionalism if offended to watch Rose Rose's amateuri efforts to stitch up her father's wound, but clearly this isn't the first time she's done it.
Give men that. I know how to do it.
Oh, I suppose you is a doctor, Homer?
Almost.
I don't need no "almost" a doctor,  Homer.
Homer can't bear to watch Rose Rose at work with the need
We should drown that damn Jack in  the vat!
Now, now, darlin'... Jack just needs  to know what business he's in.
Yeah, you really showed him, Daddy-- you just about cut your own hand  off, and all you cut off *him* was  his clothes!
You oughta know you don't go to jail  for cuttin' a guy's *clothes*. Ain't  that right, Homer?
Homer winces at the stitching.

Wally's car comes bouncing along the ditches of the close drive-in. Homer is at the wheel; Candy calls out some dri instructions. The car comes to a stop next to a speakerpo Candy leans out; she grabs the speaker and hangs it on th window. Homer sits back and drapes his arms out the windo and over the seat. He feels great.
You're a natural. You were born to  drive a car like this.
You think? Maybe I was. (looks around) I love this place!
Homer looks up at the giant movie screen.
The screen is enormous! Imagine King  Kong up *there*! Have you seen a lot  of movies here?
Yes... and no. When you come here,  you don't really care about the movie.
Homer stares at Candy in disbelief.
You don't care about the movie?
Candy looks at him for a moment.
What are you so crazy about the movies  for?

It was my favorite night at the  orphanage--movie night. We'd race  into the dining hall. Of course  everyone wanted to sit in front, so  we'd be packed in so tight you could  feel the kid next to you breathing.
At least you were never lonely.
I didn't say that. Growing up in an  orphanage, you're always lonely.  You're just never alone.
Candy is moved. Homer feels exposed; he tries to change t mood by making light of what he's said.
You're not alone in the bathroom,  or... or in the shower... you're  never alone in wanting the last piece  of meatloaaf, or even in your own  bed on a cold morning.
Candy laughs.
You don't miss it?
I miss things. I miss... people. (with certainty) I miss reading to the boys.
But you had so much *responsibility*.
I never *asked* for any  responsibility.
Just a little privacy.
Homer laughs.
Privacy is exactly the point of drive- in movies.
Did you come here with Wally--to  *not* watch movies?
At the mention of Wally they both look a little self- conscious.
Sometimes... movies mostly bore Wally.
Ah-ha. (points to the speaker) So what is that--a radio?
The *speaker*. For the movie sound.
Candy looks at Homer.
Scrunch down like this.
Candy scrunches down in her seat; Homer imitates her. Hom is focused on the giant screen.
How could you not *care* about the  movie?
You just cuddle. You come to hug...  to kiss. You don't *come* here to  watch the movie.
(teasing her) That's what *I'd* come here for. I'd  watch the movie.
Not with the right girl you wouldn't.

Homer's expression changes from exhilarated to guilty. He leans back in his seat and looks straight ahead at the sc Candy tentatively leans her head on his shoulder. Homer l afraid to breathe. From behind, with her head on his shoulder, they look lik normal couple. We track in toward the huge screen until w see only the screen. There are shadows on the black scree Suddenly the movie "King Kong" appears.

"King Kong" is playing against the bare, white wall. Fuzz is very weak, but he smiles at the sight of the love-stru Kong holding the screaming Fay Wray in his giant hand. Dr Larch runs the projector; he sits close beside Fuzzy. Whe the film breaks in the predictable place, Fuzzy makes no  protest. Dr. Larch looks at Fuzzy, who has stopped breath his eyes are closed.
Fuzzy? Fuzzy?
They are alone in the dining hall. Larch has wheeled in F for a private viewing.
Buster helps Larch lower the small coffin into the grave. The tiny gravestone says "F.S."
What are you going to tell the little  ones?
I'll tell them Fuzzy was adopted.
Why would the little ones believe  that *anyone* would adopt him?
They'll believe it because they want  to believe it.
Shouldn't we tell Homer?
If Homer wanted to know what was  happening here, he could pick up a  telephone and call us.
The boys in their beds listen to Buster inventing Fuzzy's "family."
It was a family with a better  breathing machine then the one Dr.  Larch built.
Larch leans against the wall, covering his eyes, overhear the boys.
The family that adopted Fuzzy, they  *invented* the breathing machine.  It's their business... breathing  machines.
Larch pauses; he waits to see if they believe this.
Lucky Fuzzy!
Larch almost breaks with a sudden sharp breath.
Good night, Fuzzy! Good night, Fuzzy!  Good night, Fuzzy Stone!

As the men sit at the picnic table eating their cornbread Rose Rose pours coffee. A jeep comes down the orchard roa toward them. It's Olive. Mr. Rose leads the "Good mornin' Mrs. Worthin'ton!" greeting. Olive has an armful of cloth and a fairly sizable package; she brings the latter over Homer.
Some mail for you, Homer.
Homer shakes the package; he puts the package beside the  table, unopened. Olive turns to Rose Rose.
And some clothes for you, dear-- (nodding to the cider  house) let's go see if they fit.
Mr. Rose watches Rose Rose and Olive disappear into the c house. The other men view Homer's package with curiosity, especially Peaches.
Ain't you gonna see what it is, Homer?
Mind your own business, Peaches.
Sorry, Homer...
Homer lies awake in bed; everyone else is asleep. Homer p the package out from under his bed, opening it just enoug to see what it is; then he shoves it back under his bed.
The beach at sunset. Candy and Homer, dressed for cooler  weather, are alone at the water's edge. From a paper bag, Candy is scattering some small, brightly colored pieces o broken glass.
Aren't you worried that people will  cut their feet?
Nobody will swim here until next  summer. By then, the water will have  rubbed the glass smooth against the  sand--there won't be any sharp edges.
She finds and old piece of glass among the stones and she at the high-tide mark.
See? That's last year's glass, or  from some year before. I put glass  here every year. The ocean makes it  beautiful.
Candy holds up a piece of glass to the sun for Homer to l at. The ocean is a gray-green color, the glass a paler sh of green.
Give me your hand.

She rubs the smooth piece of glass against his hand, then throws it toward the water. It falls short. Homer retriev it. Candy splashes him playfully. He chases her away from the beach, into the pine trees. Homer locks his arms arou her, from behind. He can't let go. She lets him hold her, then breaks his grip. She turns to face him. She is talle then he is, older, obviously more experienced. She initia the kiss. They drop to the ground right there; they make  love by the roots of the tree, Candy guiding him.
They come out of the woods, walking toward the car, Candy leading. We hear Candy talking just before we see her and Homer.

(increasingly upset) *Nobody* volunteers for the Burma  run--he said so himself. And nobody  knows *me* better than him! So how  am I supposed to feel? He's a bomber  pilot and I'm just selfish, I know.  Well, I'm *not* a brave little girl  and I'm *not* sorry.
She sits in the passenger seat, Homer in the driver's sea
I *know* this was right. (pause) I told you. I'm not good at being  alone. (pause; in a whisper) I told him, too.
Homer concentrates on starting the car.
(repeating herself) I *know* this was right.
Right.
Their expressions, as the car pulls away, belie their wor
Homer and Mr. Rose sit opposite each other at the picnic  table. Rose Rose stands behind her father, her hands on h shoulders, watching Homer snip out Mr. Rose's stitches--v quickly.
Slow down, Homer--don't be in such a  big hurry.
This is easy--I'm not hurrying.
You still doin' it too fast!
Job done, Homer leaves the table and hurries to the bicyc pedaling away. Rose Rose watches Homer go, as Mr. Rose fl his healed hand.
He's in a big hurry, all right. I  told you he's in trouble.
Candy and Homer sit on the dock. Candy still seems to be  wrestling with her conscience. Homer throws snails in the sea. It's cold.
Just tell me. Do you want me to go?  Do you want me to stay?
It will be okay.
*What* will be okay?
We have to wait and see. I think  that, for *everything* in life, you  have to wait and see.
Homer throws a snail with more force.
I'll just move on, get another job  somewhere.
Ray comes out onto the dock; he sees Homer throwing anoth snail.
Every time you throw a snail off the  dock, you're makin' someone start  his whole life over.
Candy throws a handful of snails into the water.
Maybe we're doing the snails a favor,  Daddy.
Ray looks at the two of them; he sighs.
It's gettin' late. I think I'll pack  it in.
Good night, Daddy.
Ray nods good night; he leaves. Homer looks expectantly a Candy.
We'll just have to wait and see.
Olive and Homer sit at the dining-room table, the remnant of an apple pie in front of them. Homer is still eating.  Pictures of Wally are on the wall.
I used to hate it when Wally went  back to college--even when it was  just college! And this was when his  father was still alive... I hated it  even then. Naturally I hate this  more.
Homer nods in sympathy. His mouth is stuffed with apple p
What I mean is... I would like it  very much if you thought you could  be happy here, Homer.
(wiping his mouth) Mrs. Worthington, I feel I'm very  lucky to be here.
There's not a lot of work in the  winter, and you'll have to tolerate  Vernon--even Wally despises him, and  Wally likes everyone.
Olive's thoughts drift; her eyes look up at a photo of Wa
I think Wally will be fine, Mrs.  Worthington--he seems indestructible  to me.
(distracted) I don't know. (intently at Homer) Just promise me one thing.
Homer is tense. Does Olive suspect about Candy?
Uh... sure.
Just promise me that, if there's a  blizzard, you'll move into Wally's  room until it's over.
They both laugh, but Homer has a hard time looking her in the eye.

The pickers are moving out; the harvest is over. Olive an Homer stand near the door to the bunkhouse, talking--we c hear their conversation. Rose Rose and the other men walk past them, carrying the last of their belongings to the t Olive and Homer walk over to the truck.
Good-bye. Have a safe trip home.  Thank you, again, for all your hard  work.
You take care now, Mrs. Worthin'ton.
They shake hands.
Good-bye, Arthur. (she hugs Rose Rose) Homer, I'll see you tomorrow?
Right.
Olive gets in her Jeep and waves as she drives off. The truck is packed. Muddy tugs on a rope that secures th load.
(to Mr. Rose) We all set, I think.

Mr. Rose nods and gets in behind the wheel. Rose Rose and Muddy get in next to him. The others are bundled up for t ride in the open back of the truck. As they're leaving, Homer waves good-bye--the pickers cal out to him.
You all take care of yourself, too,  Homer!
We see you next harvest.
Don't freeze to death, Homer.
Go on and freeze to death if you  want to, Homer.
Now, now, Jack--that just ain't right.
You just stay out of trouble, Homer!
Homer stands looking after them, after they're gone.
Homer is alone, rearranging his stuff--spreading out a bi making the place his own. (On the other beds, we see the  mattresses rolled up on the bare bedsprings.)
So, you're staying.
Homer turns; he hadn't seen Candy come in.
Olive told me. (awkward pause) You might have told me yourself.
I'm just waiting and seeing. Like  you said.
She smiles. He goes to her; they embrace. BEGINNING A MONTAGE OF THE NEXT NINE OR TEN MONTHS.
Homer, drinking coffee, is writing a letter on a note pad
Dear Dr. Larch, thank you for your  doctor's bag...
Homer is learning how to "haul" a lobster pot with Ray an Candy's guidance.
...although it seems that I will not  have the occasion to use it.

Following Ray's example, Homer is trying to "disarm" the  lobsters' big claws by blocking them shut with the little wooden wedges. Roy works quickly, never getting pinched. Candy watches, Homer gets pinched.
Barring some emergency, of course. I  am not a doctor. With all due respect  to your profession. I am enjoying my  life here.
Homer and Candy are naked. They have pulled two beds toge and made a double bed. He can't take his eyes off her.
I've looked at so many women... I  mean, I've seen *everything* about  them, *everything*... but I never  felt a thing. I felt nothing. Now...  with you... it *hurts*... to look at  you.
Edna and Angela and Larch are all reading Homer's letter, their lips moving silently as they read the words.
I am enjoying being a lobsterman and  an orchardman--in fact, I have never  enjoyed myself so much.
Olive and Homer and Candy are playing a board game around the fireplace.
The truth is, I want to stay here. I  believe I am being of *some* use.
Edna and Angela view him anxiously from the doorway as La furiously types and types.

My dear Homer, I thought you were  over your adolescence, that period  which I would define as the first  time in our lives when we imagine we  have something terrible to hide from  those who love us.
Candy is singing to the car radio, as animated and happy we've ever seen her. Homer, driving, can scarcely keep hi eyes on the road; he has to keep looking at her.
Do you think it's not obvious to us  what's happened to you?

With the radio playing (a popular song), Homer hops acros the bare floor, pulling on his boxer shorts; he opens the door to Olive, who's holding out an armload of blankets t him. He sheepishly thanks her. When Homer closes the door we see a hidden (and stricken) Candy, naked from their  interrupted lovemaking.

You're fallen in love, haven't you?  By the way, whatever you're up to  can't be too good for your heart.  Then again, it's the sort of condition  that can be made worse by worrying  about it. So don't worry about it!
Vernon and Homer are working under an apple tree; they ar poisoning mice.

Dear Dr. Larch, what I am learning  here may not be as important as what  I learned from you, but everything  is new to me. Yesterday I learned  how to poison mice. You use poison  oats and poison corn.
Supper chaos--Buster and Mary Agnes are doing their best stop a food fight while Larch and Angela and Edna are  completely absorbed reading Homer's letter.
Field mice girdle an apple tree.  Pine mice kill the roots. I *know*  what you have to do--you have to  play God. Well... killing mice is as  close as I want to come to playing  God.
Homer and Candy are watching "Rebecca".

Do I interfere? When absolutely  helpless women tell me that they  simply *can't* have an abortion,  that they simply *must* go through  with having another--and yet another-- orphan... do I interfere? *Do* I? I  do not. I do not even *recommend*. I  just give them what they want: an  orphan or an abortion. (close on Homer) You are my work of art, Homer.  Everything else has been just a job.  I don't know if you've got a work of  art in you, but I know what your job  is. You're a doctor!
The radio is playing a slow, sexy dance number. The fat l from the apple mart are dancing as they paint the interio walls of the bunk house.
I am not a doctor.
You know everything I know, plus  what you've taught yourself--you're  a better doctor then I am and you  know it!
Homer is finishing up painting the kitchen walls. When he gets to the list of rules, tacked on the wall, he removes the list and finishes painting under where the rules were
They're going to replace me, Homer!  The Board of Trustees is looking for  my *replacement*!
Two of the ladies unroll the rolled-up mattresses on the  bare bedsprings, as Vernon enters with an armload of blan and pillows.
I can't replace you! I'm sorry...
Homer holds up the list of rules, rereads it briefly; he  walks over to an unpainted beam, a support beam, and tack the rules on this beam.
Homer reads Larch's letter, sipping coffee.
Sorry? I'm not 'sorry'! Not for  anything I've done. I'm not even  sorry that I love you!
Larch sits on his ether-bed with a letter from Homer in h hand. He looks completely deflated. Angela is standing in the doorway.
I think we may have lot him to the  world. He's not coming back.

In the newly painted, spruced-up cider house, Homer and C are dancing to another slow, sexy song on the radio. He i untucking her blouse, feeling under her blouse--she start to unbutton his shirt. They kiss while they dance. But th song changes abruptly on the radio to something fast and  silly. Homer responds to the music, dancing goofily--instantly o of the mood. Candy laughs, but she picks up a pillow and  swings it at him, hitting him. He dances away from her. S throws the pillow; he ducks--the pillow lands somewhere n the door. Now Homer grabs a pillow and chases her from be to bed. She shrieks--they're both laughing. They each gra pillow and stand toe to toe whacking each other, laughing all the while, until he pins her arms behind her and,  breathing hard--and despite the stupid music that broke t mood--they are passionately kissing again. The sound of a truck is sudden and loud.
Mr. Rose's truck has arrived. The pickers are hopping out the truck, grabbing their gear.
The door opens. Hero and Peaches barge in, as Homer and C are struggling to return the pillows to the beds.
Who's that?
It's that Homer!
Muddy is right behind them. He picks up a pillow, off the floor, looking for which bed it belongs on.
It's that Candy, too...

Then comes Mr. Rose, slyly smiling, taking it all in--the no hiding what's going on. Homer and Candy are caught, th shirts untucked and half-unbuttoned--they're still out of breath. The pillows lie crazily on the beds, each one of  which has been stepped on.
Don't this place look like home?
It look nicer then home!
What have you two been doin' to make  it look so nice?
Rose Rose enters. She looks hardened, toughened--not happ She plops down her stuff on her bed, looking only at Cand
How is that Wally doing?
Oh, he's fine! I just heard from  him. He's bombing all these places...
Homer tries to help out.
(mumbling) ...bridges, oil refineries, fuel  depots...
He peters out, knowing how sick of hearing this Candy is. tries to change the subject.
Where's Jack?
There is an uncomfortable silence.
He just wasn't up for the trip.
More silence.
That Jack just never knew what his  business was.
One look at Muddy and we know something pretty bad happen to Jack.

The pickers on their ladders, all picking. Homer is now a good picker; he looks over at Rose Rose. She is slumped  against the ladder, not picking, completely ignoring an  argument beneath them in the aisle between the trees. (Mr Rose is checking over the apples Peaches has just picked.
You pickin' nothin' but cider apples,  Peaches--I hope you understand that.
They ain't drops--I picked 'em off  the tree!

Then you pickin' 'em too fast--they  ain't no better than drops to me.  See that bruise, and that one? *Half*  of these is bruised! Look at this  one! It ain't got no stem! You might  as well *step* on 'em, too--they  only good for cider.
In the aisle between the trees, Homer and Candy are argui in one of the work vehicles.
Do you think I'm having a good time?  Do you think I'm just *teasing* you?  Do you think I *know* whether I want  you or Wally?
So we should "wait and see." For how  long?
I grew up with Wally. I began my  adult life with him.
Fine. That's all there is to it then.
No! That's not all there is to it! I  love you, too--I *know* I do.
Okay, okay--I know you do, too.
(bitterly) It's a good thing I didn't have that  baby, isn't it?
Her sudden hardness leaves him speechless as they go thei separate ways. Candy drives on.
Breakfast time at the picnic table. Rose Rose by herself, away from the table. She does not look well; she suddenly goes back inside the bunkhouse.
(calling after her) Ain't you eatin' with us, Rose? (to the men) She used to eat with us. Now we ain't  good enough for her, I guess.
She ain't hungry, maybe.
She ain't hungry every mornin' 'cause  she's sick every mornin'.
Homer gets up to take his dishes inside.
When Homer comes in, Rose Rose is throwing up in the sink
You okay, Rose?
I guess you must like watchin' me be  sick...
I don't like watching anyone be sick.

Rose Rose lies down on her bed with the curtain open. The is something familiar about the way Homer approaches her  bedside; he does so with the authority of a doctor. He si on the edge of her bed with such complete self-assurance  that she doesn't protest.
How many months are you?
She just stares. But she doesn't stop him when he touches her abdomen. It's as if she knows that he knows what he's doing.
You're not yet three months, are  you?
Not yet. What do you know about it?
I know more than I want to know about  it. Who's the father?
Don't trouble yourself about it,  Homer--this ain't your business.
But you don't look very happy.
*Happy*! What are you thinkin'? How  am I supposed to take care of a baby!  I can't have a baby.
Rose, please listen. Whatever you  want to do, I can help you.
She is taken back.
What I mean is, if you don't want  to... keep the baby, I know a place  where you can go.
You think Daddy's gonna let me go  anywhere? I ain't going *nowhere*.
She rolls over on the bed, facing away from him again.
Why don't you just go back to your  pickin', Homer? I can take care of  it myself!
Rose, listen--don't *do* anything.  You know, I mean to yourself. Please  listen...
(calling) Homer! Is this a workin' day or what?
Homer and Candy are sitting at the dock.
We should take her to St. Cloud's.  That much is obvious, isn't it? Let  her make up her mind when she gets  there...
I told her! She doesn't feel she can  do that. Something about her father  not letting her go anywhere...
Well, we have to help her!
Homer doesn't respond.
We have to do *something*. Don't we? (beat) Homer?
Homer looks out over the ocean; he remains unresponsive.
Rose Rose is setting the picnic table for lunch when Cand arrives.
Hi...
Hi...
She keeps setting the table.
I've got some more clothes for you-- I just keep forgetting to bring them  with me.
I don't need no more clothes, thank  you.
(softly) Rose, I know what's going on. Homer  told me. I got pregnant, too--about  a year ago. (pause) I've been through this.
Rose Rose looks down.
You ain't been through what I been  through, Candy.
(doesn't get it) Yes, I *have*!
Rose Rose dismissively waves her hand.
Who's the father, Rose?
Rose looks at Candy and shakes her head.
You want to have the baby?
Rose Rose shakes her head again, more emphatically.
I know where you can go. Homer and I  can take you...
I can't go nowhere.
Why?
Rose Rose stays silent.
Is it the father? Does he know?
Rose Rose turns away from Candy.
You can trust me. Is it Jack? It's  not Jack, is it? It's *Muddy*! Is it  Muddy?
(almost wistfully) No. It ain't Muddy. Muddy's just...
Rose Rose stops; she can't even continue setting the tabl Her voice turns bitter, despairing.
It sure ain't Jack.
There, suddenly, is Mr. Rose, walking past them. He is  uncharacteristically tentative.
(to his daughter) I'll be up top...

Mr. Rose leaves Candy and Rose Rose alone again. Rose Ros nods almost invisibly after her father. Rose Rose looks  pointedly at Candy, nodding. Candy slowly gets it. Mr. Ro is the father! Rose Rose lets that sink in; she keeps loo at Candy with an ashamed expression.

The pickers are at work, on their ladders, when Candy run down the aisle between two rows of trees. She stops at th bottom of Homer's ladder, out of breath. Muddy and Peache and Hero, in the treetops, are watching and listening.
She won't go to St. Cloud's!
(shrugging) Well, we can't force her. It's her  decision.
You don't understand! It's her  father...
Mr. Rose *knows*?
(shouting) He's the *father*! He's her baby's  father!
The pickers can't help but hear this, too. Candy starts t leave, Homer running after her.
Wait... *wait*! Are you sure?
We've got to keep her away from that  bastard!
Candy leaves. Homer starts looking for Mr. Rose.
Smiling his enigmatic smile, Mr. Rose keeps slowly pickin while Homer stands at the foot of his ladder.
I didn't see where you was pickin'  this mornin', Homer, but you musta  worked up a big appetite. You look  like you're serious about gettin' to  your lunch today!
Is it true?
Mr. Rose stops picking, his eyes darting to see who's aro
Are you sleeping with your own  daughter?
Mr. Rose, with deliberate slowness, comes down the ladder
(slyly; still composed) I think you been stayin' up too late  at night, Homer.
You're actually having sex with your  own little girl? Is that possible?
Ain't nobody havin' *sex* with my  little girl, Homer--that's somethin'  a father knows.
You're lying. How can you... with  your own daughter!
Mr. Rose switches from sly to threatening in a split seco
Homer, don't you know what business  you in? You don't wanna go into no  business with me, Homer--ain't that  right?
Go on, cut my clothes. I've got other  clothes.
Mr. Rose is indignant.
You a fine one to be talkin' about  lies. Shame! These people took you  in. That boy Wally's at *war*!
That takes some of the steam out of Homer's superiority.
But she's your *daughter*...
And I *love* her! There ain't nobody  else gonna treat her as good as I  do! (looks away) I wouldn't do nothin' to hurt her,  Homer--you must know that.
Homer turns; he speaks over his shoulder as he walks away
She's *pregnant*. Do you know *that*?

By his expression--he looks as if he's been punched--it's clear that Mr. Rose didn't *know that*. The other pickers are on their way to lunch; it's obvious that Muddy, Peaches, and Hero already know that Mr. Rose sleeping with his daughter.

Rose Rose is sitting at the picnic table when the pickers arrive for lunch, almost simultaneously with Homer. He lo at, then looks away from, Rose Rose. Mr. Rose is the last sit down at the table as a very tense, wordless lunch beg
Homer is on a ladder picking apples. Muddy climbs a ladde on the other side of the same tree.
Don't mess in this, Homer, if you  know what's good for you.
How long's this been going on, Muddy?
Long enough. You ain't gonna stop  it.
Muddy looks all around for Mr. Rose; then he gives Homer knife.
There's my knife, Homer. It ain't  gonna do *me* no good. You give that  knife to Rose Rose, you hear?
Homer nods, pocketing the knife. As Muddy climbs down and moves his ladder to an adjacent tree, he keeps talking to Homer until he disappears in the leaves.
You best just watch you ass, Homer!  You don't wanna end up like Jack!
Homer thoughtfully continues his work.
Homer lies awake in his bed.
The pickers on their ladders in the trees; nobody is talk In the late sun, the leaves have a reddish, fiery glow.

It's much colder; the pickers are on their ladders in the trees again, but they're dressed for the cold. Homer is h on a ladder; he turns toward the view of the Worthington  house when he hears a car come to a screeching halt in th driveway. Homer sees Candy get out of Wally's car; she le the door open and runs toward the house. Parked in front Wally's car is an Army Jeep, with an ENLISTED MAN leaning against it. The indifferent soldier smokes a cigarette as watches Candy run.
No! No!
Homer descends the ladder and runs for the house, down as aisle between the row of trees. The pickers watch him run

Camera follows Homer into the Worthington house where, fr the front hall, he sees Olive and Candy (in profile) sitt on the couch. We can't see who's talking, nor do we recog the voice. As Homer comes into the living room, we see MA WINSLOW sitting in a chair (also in profile), talking to  Olive and Candy. Major Winslow is a smooth, handsome well-briefed officer the casualty branch of the Army Air Corps; he's done his  homework, but he's not all business. He's painfully aware the delicate nature of his report.

When the plane was hit, the crew  chief and the radioman jumped close  together. The copilot jumped third.  All on Captain Worthington's orders-- the captain was still flying the  plane. None of the men of the ground  could see the sky--that's how thick  the jungle was. They never saw the  plane crash--they never *heard* it  crash. They never saw Captain  Worthington's parachute, either.
Why was he missing for twenty days?

Because the crew thought he'd gone  down with the plane. They were  hospitalized for almost a week in  China before they were flown back to  India. It wasn't until that they  sorted through their gear...
Who cares about their *gear*?
Three men jumped from the plane, but  they had four compasses with them.  One of the crew jumped with Captain  Worthington's compass.
He was in Burma for twenty days  without a compass?
He followed the Irrawaddy River, all  the way to Rangoon. Somehow he managed  to avoid the Japs, but not the  mosquitoes.
Then it's malaria?
It's encephalitis B. He's recovering  at Mount Lavinia Hospital, Ceylon. (pause) Uh... Captain Worthington is  paralyzed. (Olive gasps) Waist down. He won't walk.
Candy stands and leaves the room.
(to Olive) I'm sorry.
(asks the major) There are no autonomic effects, are  there?
Major Winslow has to consult his notes.
No autonomic effects... that's  correct.
When will he be home, Major?
Four weeks or so, right around  Halloween.
Homer and Candy are sitting in the parked car in silence.
(finally) There are no autonomic effects, just  the paralysis of the lower  extremities.
Candy stares at him, uncomprehending.
Wally can have kids, a normal sex  life...
Candy cries.
Ray is throwing snails in the water. Candy sits on the en of the dock, slumped on Homer's shoulder.
How about him not needin' the friggin'  compass! How about that?
Daddy, *please*...
Ray knows that she wants him to leave. He shuffles off th dock, toward the house. He knows how they both must feel.
Good night, kids. Don't catch cold-- it's gettin' cold already.
Good night, Daddy.
Good night, Ray.
Homer tries to cuddle closer, but Candy sits up, preoccup
Just tell me. I'll do whatever you  want to do.
Nothing.
Isn't that like waiting and seeing?
No. Nothing is nothing. I want Wally  to come home. I'm afraid to see him,  too.
I know. (he kisses her) Is *that* nothing.
No, don't--that's something. Nothing  is nothing. (Homer's sad smile) Don't even look at me. I want...
Candy buries her face in his chest.
...to do nothing.

Homer holds her, doing nothing, while she sobs. As her cr subsides, Homer's thoughts are far away. With Candy slump against him, hugging him, he doesn't look at her; instead he looks out to sea and at the darkening coast, Candy's w resonating. An unfamiliar expression is on his face.
(mumbling to himself) It's a tempting idea, I know... to  do nothing.
Candy is silent. Homer feels strangely agitated; he shift his position.
(groans) Please don't move, don't go anywhere.
(overly genuine) *Go* anywhere? Of course not! That  would be *doing* something, wouldn't  it? We wouldn't want to *do*  something. Let's just sit here all  night!
(irritated) If you're trying to be funny, Homer...

(irritated, too) I'm not trying to be anything--I'm  just doing nothing! If I wait and  see long enough, then--with any luck-- I won't *ever* have to make up my  mind! Decisions can be painful, after  all...
Candy is angry; she gets to her feet and stares hard at h
Stop it! Just cut it out!
(mock surprise) You got up! You *did* something! If  you keep this up, you might be in  danger of making a *decision*!
For God's sake, Homer, Wally's been  shot down!
Candy sobs. Homer puts his face in his hands for a minute He regains his composure and stands up.
(genuinely contrite) I know, I'm sorry.
(yelling and sobbing) He's *paralyzed*!
(deadpan; just the  facts) He's *alive*. He still loves you. (pause) So do I.
(anguished) What do you want me to *do*?
He faces away from her.
(with calm resolve) Nothing. You're not the one who has  to do anything.
Homer is in semidarkness as he walks toward the cider hou
Where do you think you're going?
You gotta let me go, Daddy. Please...
Homer walks faster. When he gets to the cider house, he s Mr. Rose and Rose Rose arguing. Rose is sitting on the  bicycle, a bundle of her clothes tied up behind the seat.
You ain't goin' nowhere in the middle  of the night, girl!
I ain't your business no more, Daddy.  Please let me go.
Rose Rose starts to pedal away, but Mr. Rose stops her. S starts to struggle.
Hey, hey! Stop it. Maybe I can help.
They turn to see Homer.
You just go inside, Homer. We don't  need no help.
That's right, Homer. This ain't your  business.
She tries to break free from her father and pedal away, b he stops her again. They keep struggling.
Please listen to me! *Both* of you...
You forget yourself, Homer. This  here's my daughter! You got your own  mess to deal with--ain't that right?
Homer steps between them, which makes Mr. Rose furious.
(yelling) What business is you in, Homer?
Mr. Rose, I'm in the *doctor*  business. (to Rose Rose) If you want, I can help you. You  don't have to go anywhere.
Rose Rose and Mr. Rose stop struggling. Suddenly Homer is charge.

Muddy, Hero and Peaches smoke in their beds. Rose Rose op her curtain and peers out from her bed. She gets up and g toward the kitchen area in her nightshirt; she stops at a unused bed, now covered with white rubber sheeting--Homer medical instruments are displayed and ready. Homer finish scrubbing his hands in the sink. His surgical mask is loo tied around his neck. Mr. Rose is looking at Homer's surgical instruments when  Rose Rose joins him.
(to Homer) What's that? What's it called?
One cervical stabilizer, two sets of  dilators--Douglas points. One medium- sized curette, one small; one medium  speculum, one large; two vulsellum  forceps.
There ain't no *almost* about this  stuff, Homer--ain't that right?
Homer ignores him; he keeps naming his equipment.
Merthiolate, ether, vulval pads,  gauze--lots of gauze.
When it comes to this, you is the  real thing--is that what you sayin'?
Homer looks at Mr. Rose and Rose Rose.
No *almost* about it--I'm a doctor.
Homer turns to Peaches, Hero, and Muddy.
Get out of here, please.
Muddy herds Peaches and Hero out of the bunkhouse.
I'm stayin', Homer.
Okay. Then you can be of use.

Mr. Rose wears a surgical mask; he is sweating, even in t cold, and his eyes look stricken as he watches Homer, who performing the abortion. Mr. Rose holds the ether cone ov Rose Rose's face. He drips some ether from the bottle on cone. Cut quickly for Rose Rose's etherized face... to Mr. Rose eyes above his mask... to Homer working with his eyes tra on the speculum...
...to Muddy and Peaches and Hero huddled under the overha roof in the rain.
Mr. Rose is having a hard time breathing.
You better get some air.

The cider house in the rain. Mr. Rose staggers out; he st there in the rain, trying to regain his composure. He sta to scream. Another angle: huddled under the overhanging roof, Muddy Peaches and Hero are watching him.

Rose Rose, curled in a fetal position, listens to the rai on the roof. Candy sits on her bed beside her. She helps to sit up, to drink a glass of water; then Rose Rose lies down again. Rose Rose's expression never changes while Ca talks to her. Mr. Rose lies in his bed in the exact same  fetal position as his daughter; he too, is listening to C Homer is putting away his instruments.

The bleeding should taper off  tomorrow, but it can come back again.  The cramps will ease up, almost  entirely. The bleeding is usually  much lighter in two days. As long as  the bleeding isn't heavy, it's normal.
Muddy enters the cider house from out of the storm. He gl at Candy and Rose Rose; then at Homer. Then he speaks to Rose.
It's that Vernon--he keeps askin'  where you and Homer and Rose Rose is  at.
Tell that Vernon to mind his own  business, Muddy.
I told him that you all is sick.
Tell him what you want, Muddy--*you*  is the crew boss today.
Hero and Peaches, dripping wet, come inside. Peaches is  standing next to the list of rules tacked to the kitchen  support beam.
Look at that. Them same damn rules  is tacked up again!
Homer has finished putting his instruments away.
Why don't you put them damn rules in  the wood stove, Peaches?
As the men are murmuring their approval of this idea, Ros Rose interjects.
I want to hear what they are, first.
The men groan, but Mr. Rose won't oppose his daughter on  this subject--not this time. He just lies there.
Homer, let me hear what they are.
Homer begins to read.
"One: Please don't smoke in bed."
We heard that one already, Homer.
"Two: Please don't go up to the roof  to eat your lunch."
That's the best place to eat lunch!
"Three: Please--even if you are very  hot--do not go up to the roof to  sleep."
What do they think? They must think  we're crazy!
They think we're dumb niggers so we  need dumb rules--that's what they  think.
This is the last one.
The men groan, in mock disappointment.
"Four: There should be no going up  on the roof at night."
Why don't they just say, "Stay off  the roof!"?
Yeah, they don't want us up there  *at all*!
Homer crumples the list and throws it into the wood stove
(to Homer) That's *it*?
That's it.
It means nothin' at all! And all  this time I been *wonderin'* about  it!
They're *outrageous*, them rules!

Who *live* here in this cider house,  Peaches? Who grind them apples, who  press that cider, who clean up the  mess, and who just plain *live*  here... just breathin' in the vinegar? (he pauses) Somebody who *don't* live here made  them rules. Them rules ain't for  *us*. *We* the ones who make up them  rules. We makin' our *own* rules,  every day. Ain't that right, Homer?
Right.
Camera closes on Candy.
Homer and Candy sit and stare at the blank screen; they d look at each other. Candy grips the steering wheel of the parked car.
Please don't make me say it again.
No, that's not it--I just want to be  sure I understand you.
Candy slumps forward with her forehead on the steering wh

I *helped* you not to think about  Wally. You were so upset--you couldn't  stand worrying about him, about his  being killed and not coming back-- but when you were with me, you could  stop worrying... well, for a while,  anyway. This is how I helped you,  right?
Please... that's enough. I *loved*  you, too--you know I did.
"...did." Well, okay.
Please don't...
(sarcastically) And now that Wally's coming back,  and because he'll certainly *need*  you...
You say that as though it's some  awful thing! (angrily) I never stopped loving Wally!
Homer lets that sink in.
(still sarcastic) At least there's no more waiting and  seeing. At least I got to see the  ocean.

Candy covers her face in her hands and cries uncontrollab unstoppably. Homer's anger keeps him impervious to her te another "first" for him. He turns and looks at her with a almost clinical curiosity; then he goes back to staring a the blank screen.

location: IN FRONT OF THE APPLE MART

text: The rain has stopped but the grass is wet, the trees  glistening in the dawn light as Wally's car stops and Hom gets out. The car exits the frame in one direction; Homer walking, exits the frame in another.
As he walks toward the cider house, Homer sees Muddy and  Peaches and Hero waving to him from the roof.
Rose Rose has runned away!
She took off in the night!
She took off on the bicycle, man.
Homer starts jogging, then running toward the cider house Muddy comes down the ladder to meet him.

Rose Rose's bed is exposed. The curtains are flung open; bed is empty. Mr. Rose is still in his bed, in the fetal  position we have seen before. Mr. Rose's trancelike expre doesn't change as Homer and Muddy enter.

Ain't nobody gonna find her, Homer-- she's long gone. (pause) I swear, I didn't try and stop her-- I just wanna touch her hand before  she go. That's all I wanna do, I  swear. (pause) Where'd she get that knife, Muddy?  That looked like *your* knife--what  I seen of it.
Muddy is scared; he looks to Homer for advice.
If that was your knife, Muddy, I  wanna thank you for givin' it to her-- no girl should be goin' *hitch-hikin'*  if she don't got a good knife with  her.
(seeing the blood) Where'd she get you?
She just plan misunderstand me--I  was tryin' to give her my knife, I  was just reachin' to touch her hand.  But I understand if she misunderstand  me--it's all my fault, ain't that  right?
Homer takes the blanket off him; Muddy gasps. Homer tries examine Mr. Rose's wound. Mr. Rose smiles at him.
It's too late for the doctor now,  Homer--ain't that right?
Homer doesn't answer; he knows Mr. Rose is a goner.
(proudly) She's *good* with that knife! She's  real fast. She's a lot better with  that knife than *you* is, Muddy! And  who do you suppose taught her?
*You* taught her, I suppose...
That's right! A girl's gotta know  how to defend herself, don't she?
He winces in pain at Homer's examination.
(surprised) There's more than one laceration,  more than one cut.
That's 'cause I sticked my *own*  knife in the wound--after she go, I  sticked my *own* knife in there. I  poked it all around, I just tryin'  to find the same place she got me.
Homer finds Mr. Rose's knife. There's blood everywhere.

You listen to me: you tell them police  how this happen, you tell it *this*  way, you hear? My daughter, she runned  off--and I so sad about it that I  stabbed myself. I so unhappy that  she gone, I killed myself--that what  you say, you hear? That the true  story--ain't that right?
Homer and Muddy exchange a glance. Mr. Rose, with his blo soaked hand, suddenly grabs Homer by the throat.
Let me hear you say that! I so unhappy  she runned away that I killed myself-- that what happen here, ain't that  right?
Right?
That what happen--you lost you only  daughter so's you killed yourself!  That's what we say, all right.
That's right. I know you understand  how I feel, Homer--you is breakin'  them rules, too. Ain't that right?
Mr. Rose dies. Muddy turns away. Homer closes Mr. Rose's  eyes.

Muddy and Hero and Peaches are sitting close together on roof, like banished children. It is from their perspectiv that we see the police car and the ambulance--two men car the body out of the cider house, and a cop or two talking Homer and Olive, and Homer talking to them. We hear no  dialogue.

Homer and the men load crates of apple jelly onto a truck The mood is solemn; they work with tired focus. Candy dri up. The men are evasive with her; they find a reason to w across the mart. Candy walks to Homer, stands next to him They say nothing for a moment, until Candy breaks the sil
Do you think she'll be all right?
She knows how to take care of herself.
Candy looks away; she can't think of what to say. She sho her hands into her pockets, finds a letter there, which s hands to Homer.
This came for you a couple of days  ago. Olive asked me to bring it.  With everything happening, I guess  she forgot.
Sure. Thanks.
Homer looks at the letter from St. Cloud's; he puts it  unopened in his pocket without a second thought. Candy ca let things end there.
I know you don't think much of being  needed, or of me for that matter...
I'm sorry for what I said about Wally  needing you. It was... unnecessary.
No, I'm the one who should be sorry.  You have every right to be angry.
No. You warned me. I didn't listen,  but you warned me.
Candy looks surprised.
You told me you weren't any good at  being alone. (pause) You told Wally, too. Right?
Candy can only stare straight ahead.
(relenting) He's going to be fine, Wally's going  to be fine. I know he is.
A tear rolls down Candy's cheek, Homer wipes it away; the he stops touching her and looks off into the quiet orchar
The pickers lie in their beds, smoking. Homer is undressi He pulls the letter out of his pocket and sits down on hi bed. Homer opens the letter without enthusiasm and begins read.
Dear Homer, I am writing to tell you  about Wilbur.
Music is playing on the old phonograph as an exhausted La gives himself ether.
Edna is getting the girls ready for bed. Music continues  Over.

Larch has twisted himself on the narrow bed so that his f is unusually close to the windowsill, and when the ether  cone starts to fall off his face--and his slack hand trai down, off the side of the bed--the cone becomes caught ag the windowsill. He tries to turn his face away from the cone, but he pres his face into the sill--thus holding the ether-soaked con over his mouth and nose. His hands twitch, he's trying to wake up; the hand that holds the ether bottle lets the bo fall. The bottle shatters against the sill; the ether spr running red with blood from a cut on Dr. Larch's hand or  finger. Music continues Over. It's a funeral.

Buster is bringing in the wood as the music plays Over. B smells the spilled ether. He heads toward the dispensary, sniffing. Camera follows him into the dispensary. In the dispensary: Buster approaches Larch's ether-bed.
Dr. Larch? Dr. Larch?
He drops the armload of wood and runs for help.
Angela enters. She feels for Larch's pulse; Larch is dead Angela opens a window. She pull's Larch's body away from windowsill. Buster joins her on the bed.
I can assure you that the overdose  was entirely accidental.
Homer finishes reading the letter; he puts it down, gets and walks to a window. He stares into the night.
Let us be happy for Dr. Larch. Dr.  Larch has found a family.
Good night, Dr. Larch! Good night,  Dr. Larch! Good night, Dr. Larch!
Homer wipes a tear off his cheek.

The truck is packed for the long trip south; it passes by the packing house, which looks closed for the season. No else is about. Muddy is driving slowly, his arm out the o window. In the back, huddled among their belongings, are  Peaches and Hero (on one side) and Homer (on the other). pickers are trying to draw Homer into their conversation, while Homer is giving the apple farm a good-bye look. He made up his mind about something.
You ever see a palm tree, Homer?
He ain't never been outta Maine!
Ain't you sick of pine trees, Homer?
Homer just smiles and shakes his head.

As the pickers' truck drives past, Homer is on the side o the truck nearest the Worthington house and driveway; he  sees Olive and Candy and Ray helping Wally out of the car and into a wheelchair. A NURSE stands by. Wally is wearing what appears to be an oversized officer' coat or flight jacket, his face looking small in the over clothes. He can't move his legs at all, and his mouth is  drawn into a tight-lipped smile.
Let me tell you somethin' about  Florida, Homer.
The Sunshine State!
It's so nice 'n' warm down there,  you can pick them grapefruits and  oranges *naked*, if you want to.
Olive is dissolved in tears. Candy is sobbing; she kisses Wally, without ceasing, while he haltingly touches her fa her hair. In the truck the smile is gone from Homer's face. He shak his head.
Thanks, guys... I'd like to go with  you. But I've got to move on.
Yeah, well... you could move on with  *us*, man! You could move on somewhere  *warm*!
Homer, stayin' in Maine ain't movin'  on!
This makes all the pickers laugh, but Homer just smiles a shakes his head. He watches the Worthington house disappe from view.

A CONDUCTOR, taking tickets, comes to Homer, who is bette dressed than we've ever seen him; he is looking at his so reflection in the black window-glass of the night train w the conductor gets his attention. When the conductor move on, Homer takes Angela's letter out of his breast pocket; skips ahead to the end.
Dr. Larch often wondered how the  world was treating you.
He talked a lot about you, hoping  you would be of use, whatever you  were up to.
Angela and Buster and Mary Agnes and Edna carry Larch's  coffin; they set it down by the raw hole. The pile of fre dirt stands out against the new snow; the hole is black  against the new white.
"Oh, Lord, support us all the day  long..."
We see the wheelbarrow with the gravestone.
"...until the shadows lengthen and  the evening comes, and the busy world  is hushed, and the fever of life is  over, and our work is done."
We see the faces of the girls praying for Larch (Mary Agn too) as Edna finishes her favorite prayer.
"Then, in Thy mercy grant us a safe  lodging, and a holy rest, and peace  at the last."
Camera closes on Homer, sleeping to the sound of the rock train. Angela's letter lies in his lap.
Amen! Amen! Amen!
The train stops, blowing snow. Homer steps off the train  carrying a suitcase and Dr. Larch's bag. The disapproving stationmaster is still disapproving. Music plays Over,  something triumphant.
Homer makes his way up the hill toward the orphanage. Mus Over.

Edna is breaking up fights; this time, instead of fightin over snowballs, the orphans are fighting over their pumpk Suddenly Homer tops the brow of the hill and they all see him. Buster is the first to catch sight of Homer; he runs toward him. Mary Agnes also sees Homer; she immediately t away and runs inside. Music FADES OUT Over.
Mary Agnes crashes into the bathroom and stumbles up to t mirror; she starts to fix herself up with shaking hands.

Everyone has heard the news; they come on the run. The  children flock around Homer, hugging him. Homer takes Ang and Edna in his arms. Mary Agnes joins the group. Homer t in how changed, how attractive she is. They smile awkward at each other.
Homer's suitcase is open on the bed; we see Homer's hands he begins to unpack. Smaller hands reach in and root thro the clothes.
Did you bring something for me?
Curly continues his search. Homer thinks for a second; th reaches into his pocket and pulls out the piece of pale-g glass.
You know what? I did.
Homer hands the piece of glass to Curly.
It's from the ocean. It's for you.
Curly is duly impressed; he walks away to examine his new treasure. Homer continues unpacking. He pulls his X ray o and puts it aside.
What are you doing here?
Homer turns to see Buster, Mary Agnes, Angela, and Edna i the doorway.
We made up a room for you.
Wouldn't you be more comfortable by  yourself?
Homer smiles; he nods. Angela and Mary Agnes start to put Homer's things back in his bag. Edna picks up the X ray and looks at it with a s expression.
Homer, do you know what this is?
Sure. It's my heart.
(shakes her head) Actually, it's Fuzzy's. There's  nothing wrong with your heart.
Fuzzy's?!
Dr. Larch wanted to keep you out of  the war, Homer--that's why he did  it. That's why he told you it was  yours.
Homer is stunned; he puts his hand to his heart.
I think he worried about his own  heart. He said it would never stand  up to Homer Wells going off to war.
Homer takes that in; he nods. Mary Agnes touches him  sympathetically.

Homer looks at his fake diplomas; they are now framed and hanging on the office wall. Homer surveys the office, as for the first time; he sits down in the desk chair, as if slowly getting used to his new position.

Homer reads to the boys from "David Copperfield". While h voice is strong--positive, optimistic, certainly reassuri to the boys--there is in the conclusion of the chapter  something that distracts him. He seems to hesitate; he mi a line or two, and perhaps he purposely skips one or two  others. (Possibly Homer's eyes wander ahead, to the title the next chapter: "I Make Another Beginning.")

"Thus I began my new life, in a new  name, and with everything new about  me... I felt... like one in a dream...  The remembrance of that life is  fraught with so much... want of  hope... Whether it lasted for a year,  or more, or less, I do not know. I  only know that it was, and ceased to  be; and... there I leave it."
Homer stops and looks at the boys' faces.
What happens next?
Homer smiles.
That's tomorrow, Curly. Let's mot  give the story away.

Homer puts out the lights and leaves the boys in the fami semi-darkness. Seconds, later, the closed door to the hal is flung open, flooding the room with light from the hall and Homer, dressed in his long white laboratory coat and  looking every inch the doctor, delivers his best imitatio of Larch's popular blessing.
Good night, you Princes of Maine!  You Kings of New England!

On Copperfield and Steerforth and Curly as the door to th hall is closed and semi-darkness prevails in the room aga Copperfield, smiling, shuts his eyes. After a second, the wide-eyed Steerforth shuts his eyes, too. Then Curly. The last to close his eyes is Buster.
